posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I have a 17 yr old Marin, I think Bobcat Trail. It has seen a lot of use. I now use it mainly for commuting during winter, 6 miles to each direction. In summer I use a single gear. The speed difference is pretty staggering, 8mph vs 15mph on average. I think the Marin could use some love now. The wheel hub bearings are still original, they have not seen any maintenance. Few years back I swapped out most of the drivetrain myself: derailleurs, chain, cassette, BB. It still has a suspension fork that has been locked in place, no maintenance. I would like to have the hub bearings serviced, and fork changed to a rigid one. How likely will I have a noticeable improvement in my speed? I've also toyed around with the idea of buying into the gravel bike meme but I fear it's not that different from my trusty old Marin, and I can leave this old bad boy almost everywhere unlocked because it looks so beaten.

Because it's an awful experience. I live in an urban sprawl. You either ride on the sidewalk (legal and culturally acceptable fuck off) and deal with occasional pedestrians and even worse cars pulling in and out of shit; or you ride in the "bike lane" which is 3 feet of pavement separated by a white line on a road where cars are going 50mph. Businesses don't survive on poor students dreams, but on people who work and make good amount of money. The latter don't want to be dependent on public transit or bikes, and if they feel like a city is traffic hell they will change their destination the next time.

Something I noticed about the malls that are managing to survive have been shifting into the service and community space. Things like the food court, gyms, salons, nails/brows, and hell, there's even an old time cobbler in mine that managed to survive. Growing out of malls being an informal teenage hangout, they've now become an official space for events and congregations, especially the older crowd. There's even a church in one of the malls near me.

In the modern era, the old model of a collection of stores isn't profitable business practice anymore, but the service and rental space model fits the modern economy much better

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Something not mentioned often in these discussions is time. As a resource, time is valuable. In a lot of areas even if the terrain is bikeable it can represent a big time investment. Example;
Car commute to office: 15min to drive, 5min to park.
Bike commute to office: 30-50min depending on the bike. 5-10min to change into at least office casual.
Train commute: 1hr but it's brain off. Can nap, read, listen on train.

I bike because I like biking but it can quickly increase commute time. If you work close because you didn't want a long commute and didn't already like to bike its a hard sell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1883244
You're simply using worst-case scenarios. If I don't have to drive my kids to school, that's 5-15 mins I'm saving every commute, plus however much time is needed to get kids to wherever they want to go. If I can just pedal faster to get back home, I'm not going to have to perform cardio that day, 30 mins saved. Time differences are bound to be lessened at places that suffer from gridlock.

Giving people the infrastructure to bike comfortably, safely and efficiently across cities tends to increase bike ridership, that's just how it is.

>>1864713
No budget. Just tried to stay frugal. I tentatively had 5000$ in mind but I was way under that. Even several hotel days and a spa day in Salt Lake City, and lots of eating out. You could do this way cheaper than I did. Rode with some guys who used an old bean can for their cooking pot. They hardly spent a dime on anything but food. Met other guys who stayed in hotels every night.

Tips:
Get clip in pedals. I rode the first 3500 without them, and the last 700 with them, and I'm glad I switched. I'm sure everyone else knows that but I'm not a bike fag so I didn't really know how much "better" they are.
Don't give up. I didn't train and I almost quit my second day in. I almost quit everyday for 2 weeks. It was all mental. I know touring people are way into it but this was my first tour, so it was all new to me.
Talk to everybody. That is the true magic of touring. I had so many interesting things happen.
I would advise anyone to get bigger than 32 cm tires. The offroading was never fun.
Do NOT use downtube shifters. Get really easy to use indexing shifters. It sucked shifting this thing.
Kickstand is not optional. I didn't get one until Kansas, and it made things so much better.
Get the best and lightest backpacking camping gear. I had an un-insulated air mattress and it was too cold to sleep in the snow. I had some hard nights. I also had a cheap 2 person tent, because I'm tall and sleep diagonally, but a smaller tent would have been so nice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1864746
Lone peak alta handlebar bag. Great bag overall. Removable so I kept my valuables in it and used it like a purse when I left my bike. It was the only bag that wasn't waterproof so in storms I would put my phone and wallet and bible and stuff in a ziplock bag.
All 4 panniers were Ortlieb. Obviously they are great. I had to use electrical tape on my racks to fill the clamps though. No big deal.
Axiom Journey DLX Low Rider Front Rack - My bike only has one set of studs, and this rack fit. In hindsight, I would rather have a front rack that is one piece and that I could put something on top of. But the front racks worked well.
Ibera Bike Rack - Bicycle Touring Carrier Plus+ for Disc Brake Mount, Frame-Mounted for Heavier Top & Side Loads - After 1000 miles or so one of the screws down low sheared off. They were just 5 mm. Cheap Chinese steel. I drilled out the holes to 6 mm and just put through bolts in. RIP the frame but I had to keep going.
I had 3 spokes break on the rear wheel on 3 different days, all near each other, (got them repaired one by one),with the last time the back wheel bent too much to ride. Had a new wheel made and kept going. I had to hitchhike back 100 miles which sucked.
My clothes were all wool, which meant I didn't have to do laundry all the time. Sea to summit pillow, and towards the end an R6.3 sea to summit pad. Kelty 40 degree down mummy bag with a hefty liner. Pocket rocket stove (stolen in Kentucky by drugged out hillbillies). Spare tire, spare tubes, spare spokes. Hose clamps and zip ties were my repair parts, and they held my broken rack in place for a while. What else do you want to know?
>>1864764
Thanks man! I'm pretty proud of myself right now.

I had the 12 map set of the Trans-America route. I did about 2/3s of the trail, and 1/3d my own route. Those maps and that route are absolutely amazing. There are so many great places and people hosting cyclists. Also warmshowers is king. But really I loved the solitude and camping so much. Two girls offered to sleep with me for free, and I was also offered mushrooms, and lots of beer and weed. I'm not a degenerate though; just thought it was interesting that some people are impressed by the mundane. I didn't have a bike computer, but I think that would be nice. I used a SHIMANO Dynamo DH-3N72 Generator Hub, and a Sinewave rectifier. It works, but not as well as I had hoped. I would usually charge phone and lights where there was an outlet somewhere.

>>1864982
So that night my stove got stolen was surreal. I was not prepared for the cold wave that hit, so I didn't sleep well. I heard these hillbillies all around in the woods hooting at each other. I don't know how else to describe it, because I've never heard anything like it. They would let out a long hoot, then call something out like "War da fuk yoo at?" Then repeat a couple times, at which point another hoot would come from another direction with some reply. Some Kentucky people I had trouble understanding because of how thick their accents were. So I knew those people were around, I just didn't think they were so close, and I never heard them right outside my tent stealing my stuff.
But that part of Kentucky was devastated by floods earlier this year. It was actually really really sad to ride through and see the destruction. There were all kinds of clothes and trash up in the trees above the rivers, and houses destroyed. At first I just thought it was a really trashy place, but then I learned what had happened. I hope whoever stole my stove can actually benefit from it and doesn't use it to just cook drugs with. But who knows.

Do you have any good pics of your bike all loaded up? I had 3 months to figure out everything I want to do differently on my next tour (if there is a next tour)

Because hookers just offer because it's their job. It doesn't give you the self esteem boost. The first girl was pretty young. She was the maid in a run down motel I was in. She came into the hot tub I was in after her shift, and after talking a bit she asked to come back to my room and spend the night. Obviously she was horny. >>1864986
>How did you kept your gear safe during your trip? What did you do when going for grocery errands?
If I was at a Walmart I would lock it outside. But most of the time errands were in small places like dollar general, or a restaurant. I would just leave it outside, but take my handlebar bag with all my valuables. 99% of the trip was in small town white America, which is the least threatening locale I can imagine. Also, it's a 62 cm bike that weighs over 100 pounds. Most people would have trouble stealing it. Also, I figured most people don't really understand panniers, and wouldn't think about trying to take them. Most cross country people I met also mostly just left their bikes unlocked. It never felt like a big worry.
>How is the whole dynamic of having a bike with you 24/7?
It's really easy and I got used to it fast. Most daylight hours were spent either riding or camping right next to the bike. I did several warmshowers, and always just left my bike at their homes. I guess the first few days it was weird having the bike around all the time, but it quickly just felt like my second skin. It felt more strange walking than it did riding.

>>1865168
Cargo cages hose clamped on your fork. Strap dry bags on them. Or just regular bottle cages there, with storage containers in them and straps for extra security.

A frame bag for inside the triangle.

I would run a rear rack. You could either get some better panniers or just strap bags on it. If you're riding offroad then ortileib-style panniers with rigid hooks are not ideal. You want panniers with bungey style hooks. A lot of old ones are like that. Like pic rel style of attachment.
You could also zip tie a metal basket on the rack and put things in that.

Some good straps are critical. Ones that cinch down not just bungeys with hooks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I love seeing oc on /n/.
It's the lifeblood this board lacks.
Your posts had me looking through my old pics for an hour. My longest-ever tour was a hilly 1600 miles (OH-WV-PA-MD-VA-DC-VA-NC-TN-KY-OH).

>Get clip in pedals
Haha
I never post about touring stuff, but maybe I should. I like flat pedals & one particular kind of Vans, but that's way to flexy for laying down miles, so I made custom carbon fiber inserts to reduce shoe flex while pedalling. They're not great for walking around, but it was no great task to untie my shoe & pull the insert. I also reasoned that since they're a commodity shoe, if I somehow ruined a pair along the way, I could just grab another (but that never happened).

>Do NOT use downtube shifters
The #1 advantage of moving away from dt shifters is being able to use a larger framebag. Pic is what I use on an olde 63cm steel frame, so you could fit something similar, and still have room for two side-entry bottles inside the triangle. I don't care for most bikepacking stuff, but I'm 1000% into framebags.

Really, the main reason I got started with sewing was so I could make all of the bike bags & camping gear I wanted. The machine 'paid for itself' after the first bag I figure. I had one pair of panniers (my Ortlieb grocery getters), but ended up making two new pairs to get what I wanted. In the same way that the framebag fits the frame, the panniers are the largest that fit my racks, no heel strike, stiff, external 'drying' features, etc.

I also made a fanny pack (my 'purse'), and a hammock setup. Got tired of messing around with a tent, pad, uneven ground & wildlife. So a hammock & tarp & underquilt & top quilt. RIP old down duvet. Sounds like a lot, but it packs quite well, and weighs less than my old tent setup.
I swear, some day I will take the right pics during the construction process & divest my sewing knowledge here.

Thanks, each sticker comes with a story, or at least a person associated to it, so I like them there for memory. Some of them are shit paper ones and they are getting rekt by the weather though.

>you burning out on being itinerant at all?
I've been living the hobo life on and off since I was 22, gonna turn 34 this year. Not everything with a bike. This is probably the longest time I've been doing it non-stop. But I guess only a bit, mainly due to age and also I almost left this life after spending a year+ of the pandemic with a gf in Guatemala, but she broke my heart and now I'm back at it again. I kind wanna reach Patagonia by the end of this year, more because weather plays a bigger factor the more South I go and also because I wanna reach my goal and see what I do from there.

>Good at making friends on the road?
Yeah, I've been an introverted shy kid most of my life but this way of living forces you to be social and open up. Plus being able to speak almost fluent Spanish is really making the whole social experience so much better. When I entered Mexico I only knew 2 words in Spanish so it was a very different experience.

>working?
Yeah, when I get a chance, I'm a cook so I either find work in restaurants when the pay is good or if I find a cheap/free place to stay in a tourist town I just come up with something to make with local ingredients and sell it to tourists.

>Apparently the south - west coast isn't particularly interesting
There's pretty neat secluded beaches there but other than that is straight roads and not much else, at the end of february the Algarve and Alentejo's coast should be ok for traffic but when you reach Lisbon metro area and up there's lots of really heavy traffic. But if you enjoy pretty views of the ocean then that's your route.

>As for wild camping, I heard the laws were relaxed a bit?
No, that's not true. Wildcamping is illegal, simple as that. And due to #vanlife people flooding to Portugal and parking all over the place it generated some animosity some time ago. Now it's not really enforced on campers and most people don't care but if for some reason police sees you, you can be fined. Not likely at all, should be said, but please be mindful of that if you decide to set a tent. Sleeping bag you're fine.

>And what do you mean by safety?
I just meant keeping your bike safe if you leave it to go do some errands. Around Setúbal do be aware of gypsies, there's plenty of them there in a couple problematic neighborhoods.

>I see people using the N2 national road to cycle
Kek that's what I meant by "countryside". I followed that exact route, you go through quainter towns but it's not as impressive as cycling by the ocean. It has less traffic and has indeed developed a scene with both cyclists and bikers, pic related.

Value added bump:

Here is the update my bike build.

I have no idea about this company "Serious", only that they existed in Germany, and are no longer found anywhere.

This bike is a rough copy of the Kona Sutra with some slightly cheaper parts here and there but at half the price:

https://www.probikeshop.com/en/gb/serious-yego-trekking-bike-green-2020/196257.html

Got it in 2020, did a bunch of tours in my country, worked out really well.

This year (>>1882020), I've added a few upgrades:

- TRP spyre C brakes
- Ryde Sputnik rims on both wheels. Front has a 3d32 Shimano hub, the best value for money (https://www.cyclingabout.com/best-dynamo-hub-bicycle-touring-bikepacking/)
- A friend built the wheels, who used to do so professionally for various amateur and semi pro riders
- B&M USB-werk power adapter thingy for my electronics and stuff
- New front and rear lights
- Bunch of other crap; e.g.: oversized waterbottle holder, nalgene bottle holder

Still am going to upgrade the pedals.
The drive train might need replacement after this tour, but I'm very impressed with the Alivio set that I have.

>>1885683
>Any tips on how to deal with Portuguese drivers?
Watch out for BMW and Seat Ibiza, specially if the driver is on the younger side, they're well known for being small brained. Drivers here don't actively try to hurt cyclists but they do commit plenty of traffic offenses so have that in account and ride accordingly.
Since you're crossing the Vicentine coast (Algarve-Alentejo) in early march there's no need to sweat it, traffic will not be that heavy at all, the problem starts around mid May.
Lisbon-Porto corridor has heavy traffic year round but I took a look at your map and you are sticking to actual coastal and secondary roads and avoiding N(acional) roads, if you do that then you'll be following a much safer route with slower speeds. Try to do that.

>my strategy is to setup right before sunset, and get up before sunrise
If you do that then you're golden honestly. Forests there are plenty, mostly Eucalyptus with lots overgrown underbrush you can find places to camp. You can also ask farmers permission to camp for the night on their land, most will have no problem with it.

>I doubt that there will be many GNR about
And you would be right to assume that, but don't fuck around with fires because they'll show up if you do. I've had drones being flown over my campsite looking for forest fires.
Remember what I've said before, it's unlikely you have problems camping but it's still illegal and when that's the case you are always dependent on the mood of the law enforcement goons if they catch you. Play it safe and smart.

>Damn, any more shit spots you can describe?
This highlighted part of your route is shitty, it's the suburbs of Lisbon so even though most people are your common working class, law abiding folk, there's also many gypsies, africans and criminal scum there. I've been there a few times and I've wandered around the supposedly dangerous places alone and half drunk without a single problem but at night I don't recommend you camping there.

1/2

posts.com: How do you deal with bike cases for one-way flights? Either I need to fly to one end of the tour and cycle home or I ride to the destination and fly home, acquiring a case there. The destination (Key West) is small so it would be impossibles to source a case there and backtracking to Miami would definitely be non-ideal. I think want I really would like is the to ability to order or send it to a secure address/business and then pick it upon arrival. Looking into the possibility of the UPS store or some kind of "porter service" being able to do this. The complexity of this type of planning suck some of the enjoyment of the simplicity out of it. Makes me just want to plan a more extreme round trip tour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1886345
You don't need or want a case.
Go to a bike shop and get a cardboard box from them. They get them in all the time and throw them away. It will be free. A larger chain store will always have these boxes on hand but a smaller one you might want to call and ask them to save one for you.

They will also likely have a bin filled with packing doodads, the fork end-spacers, plastic and foam, that you could pad it out with. You'll have to take the front wheel, seatpost, and bars off but the rest of the bike can stay pretty much together.
When I ship a bike to someone I autistically wrap and pad it all and ziptie/tape everything together so nothing can move or rattle and it's all padded out but that's not really necessary for touring you can basically just put your stuff in there quickly and it will be fine. Just pay minor attention to ensuring the sharp things won't poke through the box. I think the box can usually fly with you as a piece of luggage.

Then at your destination you can just throw it all away. Take a knife and cut/flatten the cardboard up and it won't be much for a recycling bin. Pretty easy to talk someone into letting you use theirs if there's nothing obvious and public to use.

If you want to send it to somewhere you could send it to a bike store and give them a box of beers or something to let you assemble it there. Most bike shops will be filled with people who have toured or want to support you doing it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1788808
Hi there, OP here.
I'm actually from the US. Fun fact about all the road/highway grass stuff, that's usually handled by the local county officially, and contracted out to local farmers for next to (or literally) nothing in reality. Farmers get to keep the grass clippings for silage, and may or may not get a small stipend from the local government. County and state parks really only mow an insignificant portion of the acreage of public land in their localities, because small towns/counties only have a small number of parks crews, and states have theirs spread among multiple public use land areas.
But I must admit, the landscaping expenses for just good old fashioned grass aren't wild, and may even be comparable to regularly replacing pavers as they get worn out. More and more I'm not seeing downsides to grass tramways.

Keeping grass short also helps get rid of water faster, which is good for infrastructure.

>>1808215

>>1808376
Most likely, nothing. APS rails aren't live unless fully covered by a tram (works by each individual 10-ish meters long conductor rail segment being switched on by a very short range radio signal). So assuming you'd go and short the APS rail to the rolling rail, the possible scenarios are:
>driver sees wire, hits the big red stop button (which may cause death and/or injuries, due to excessive deceleration throwing a few passengers off their feet)
>driver doesn't see wire. Drives over it, rail goes live.
At which point it could go either way:
>wire too thin: wire melts. Nobody ever realizes anything happened
>wire thick enough: somewhere within a few meters to a few hundreds of meters, a big breaker trips. You just made some tramway operator's day miserable.

What you actually want to do is trick the APS >>1820343 rail into thinking there's a tramway above it.

>>1820343
Wheel flange grease, brake dust and depending on how maintained your shit is, various amounts of gearbox oil, brake fluid or coolant

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1823144
Can this shit fail and keep rail live all the time?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1824342
>Can shit fail?
It shouldn't, but if anything worked as intended transportation accidents investigators wouldn't have a job.
Keeping the rail live continuously is highly unlikely, what may reasonably happen however would be some form of coupling between the "wake up" antennas of two consecutive rail sections, leading to a rail segment going live before a tram reaches it (or after it left it). That could be due to some very specific kind of debris, poorly placed third party systems, like signaling loop antennas overlapping two APS rails typically, but Alstom is pretty anal about that and it would need gross negligence to be built as such (I do know of a few such cases but none lead to any accident so far).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1860569

You have no idea how right you are. Cape gauge has been a disaster for railway capacity and speeds in Japan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1860569
>>1864001
>capacity
The gauge has fuck all to do with that. All cape gauge trains in Japan are 3 meters wide, which is the same as the standard gauge parts of EU.
>speed
JR Hokkaido tested 200km/h operation on cape gauge in Seikan Tunnel for Aomori-Hakodate services back when Hokkaido Shinkansen seemed like it wouldn't happen, but they were already in their current financial downward spiral so they abandoned the idea(which some argue helped the push to have the government finance Shinkansen via JRTT). Here's a video about it, even with some test footage:
https://youtube.com/watch?v=-C34tJRY43k
If anything, the problem is the opposite. They wanted more twisty track to save money on tunneling and bridging, but that meant they couldn't raise speeds for intercity transit down the line. For example there is a line between Hiroshima(1.2m people) and the Izumo/Matsue/Yonago metropolitan area(~400k people total), but because it slows down to as low as 25km/h for sharp curves and potentialy falling rocks, everyone just takes the bus, which is why there's no direct train nowadays.

https://news.mynavi.jp/article/20221030-kamearikanamachi/
A group is now suing JR East and Tokyo Metro, asking for ~200USD compensation from national government, by claiming their fare system constitute illegal discrimination against specific group of passengers
After year 1971, due to the Five Direction Commute Operation, Joban line local trains can no longer access Ueno station directly and are instead through run toward Tokyo Metro, and for passengers on Joban line stations only served by local trains between Kita-Senju station and Matsudo station, there are two possible transfer locations to Ueno, either via Kita-Senju or Nippori.
Transferring via Kita-senju is cheaper as it is totally within Joban line, but Joban line local trains stop at Metro station at Kita-senju, passengers must move across transfer path across multiple floors to reach the real Joban line platform, which is said as being difficult to people with lower mobility like elderly. On the other hand, transfer via Nippori is more convenient, however it involve going from JR to Tokyo Metro and then back to JR's route, thus minimum fare is being charged three times and resulted in 40% more expensive fare.

Videos like this from the YouTube channel offer much insight on plan and prospect of future of Japanese railway.

This one specifically mention Second Seikan Tunnel plan.
> If freight trains are gone from Seikan tunnel, and Hokkaido Shinkansen is to upgrade to 320km/h, then trip time from Shin Aomori to Shin Hakodate Hokuto can shorten from about 1 hours to just above 30 minutes.
> But the Second Seikan Tunnel proposal involve a 31km-long tunnel at up to 2.5% gradient. The shorter tunnel length help save construction cost, but require electrifying the overland section of Tsugaru line, and also building a new freight-dedicated line on Hokkaido to connect to Kikonai, and the gradient will require extra locomotives to push the freight trains, which will cost freight trains more to operate
> And it only suggest a single tracked route for freight trains, despite more freight trains than passenger trains in Seikan tunnel now.
> But higher cost and limited capacity for freight trains likely wouldn't be a problem, because the proposal have roads
> The proposal expect >3/4 freights to be shift from ferries toward trucks in the tunnel, killing most ferries, in line with past examples like Aqualine and Akashi bridge. Wouldn't the same apply to freight trains too?
> Isn't this the reason they only draw single track for freight? Or even no need for freight trains and the road part suffice?
> Not to mention a road tunnel will also let bus and cars connecting Hokkaido directly to Honshu
> With cars and trucks travelling through Hokkaido and Honshu with the new tunnel, fate of Hakodate Main Line will be set in stone, and JR Freight mentioned if they can't operate freight trains toward Hokkaido then they might sunk their northern end of operation to Sendai
> This will doom not just rails in Hokkaido, but also Tohoku/Hokuriku 3sectors, and even Uetsu/Ou/Tohoku Main Line will no longer have guarantee from freight demand to continue survive

> If the exchange of rail freight between Hokkaido and the rest of the country ceases, the amount of freight on the Tohoku Line, the Nihonkai Jukan Line, which passes through Akita, Niigata, etc. will also shrink, and the land and facilities at stations will not be used, and income and expenditure of JR Freight will deteriorate significantly, the business will be forced to downsize. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1876971
>Why does JR always seem to sell off/treat like shit the conventional lines these days after a shinkansen line opens parallel?
Because Japan explicitly made a law that let them do so. At the time of ~1970s-1980s, politicians seeing the opening of Shinkansen and degrading performance on old lines caused by lost of former limited express services, which ended up with bringing massive debt and operating lost to JNR, try to avoid this situation by holding local governments fiscally responsible for the construction of Shinkansen. Letting them bare the burden of operating the local rail line is part of the program.

>If a third sector operator can make money after buying those lines from them, they could still technically make money on them no?
Many of the profit are driven by streamlined operation, new fare structure, and higher rate for through freight trains, that wouldn't be possible if the line remain under JR.
Also, operating conventional line cost much extra money, even if they remain profitable now there's no guarantee it will be same 30 years down the line when population further shrink and concentrate toward metropolitan area. And even if fare income do be able to cover operation cost of trains on conventional line, it might be taking away intercity passengers from the Shinkansen, which mean JR will still be earning much less from passengers travelling between two places compared to if they take Shinkansen, while costing extra to operate two different set of service on two different tracks and platforms using two different vehicles, as opposed to using only a single Shinkansen train to transport everyone.

Unlike Europe or Muricca, most Japanese stations despite many of the big ones being the busiest in the world are very unimpressive architecturally. https://youtu.be/3-QmOoXuwaQ
Oita Prefecture organized a symposium on East Kyushu Shinkansen and proposed a different route, going along the Kyushu Shinkansen until Shin-Tosu and then diverging eastward through Hida and Yufu to Oita.
>Oita - Hakata is faster
>Oita - Osaka doesn't require a slow switchback(which makes up most of time lost on the longer route anyway)
>there's no need to deal with JR West about the fact they own the shinkansen track immediately west of Hakata station
>the parallel conventional line for JR Kyushu to 3rd-sectorize is now the barely profitable Kyudai Main Line instead of the 20000+ transit density section of the Nippo Main Line
>Hida and Yufu, both already reputable tourist destinations, get a better connection with rest of the country, meaning more tourist money
>Hida especially since they got fucked by landslides breaking the Hitahikosan Line and JR Kyushu deciding the ridership is too low to repair it and replacing it with BRT
>Tosu will gain a lot from being at the Shinkansen crossroads so they'll support it
>Nagasaki will support it because it puts more pressure on Saga to get on with completing the Nagasaki Shinkansen
>all of that outside support will help get the line actually built
The only loser in this situation is Nakatsu, which already has Sonic and Nichiran connecting it to Oita and Kokura in 40 minutes or so two times per hour

https://tabiris.com/archives/chiikikokyokotsuhou/
>government approved a draft law to revise the Act on Revitalization and Revitalization of Regional Public Transport and other related laws
>there are now 3 basic pillars of the Act
>1) "Restructuring Councils" will be created for railroad local lines, based on requests from local governments or railroad operators
>government will provide support for the holding of the councils, surveys, and demonstration projects, all funded by government
>content of the consultation and the demonstration experiments based on the consultation have been made statutory, so local governments can't just get away with saying the same thing again and again
>lines failing to prove being investment worthy will be converted to BRT, to be ran by the owner of the converted railway
>but this only covers lines that span multiple prefectures(or sub-prefectures in Hokkaido) or are parts of multi-prefecture routes
>2) "Consultative Fares"
>basically JR companies no longer have to use the same ticket price across the whole network
>and can hike them locally after consultation with local and national government
>3) "Area-wide Agreement Operation Project"
>public transport subsidies are now area-wide rather than for specific routes
>this comes after successful trials on select bus networks, now affecting all bus, rail and cab subsidies
Number one sounds very scary, but in practice I can't think of many places where it can be applied. The article gives Geibi Line as an example. From a quick look at a map I can see Nichinan Line(Kagoshima/Miyazaki), that part of Inbi Line that is bypassed via Chizu Express(Tottori/Okayama), Obama Line(Kyoto/Fukui), Senmo Line(Hokkaido), maybe Hanawa Line(Akita/Iwate) but it wouldn't make sense to challenge it's viability while it's still being rebuilt(unless "see, bus replacement is good enough" counts as a demonstration project). Yodo line is already in closure talks, and Yonesaka Line might as well be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1890994
from right to left
>Oito Line(JR West section)
It's fucked, they already had one of those "Restructuring Councils" >>1889689 mentions in 2019 except it wasn't legally binding, now JR West can just ask for another one and then get an easy bus conversion. The JR East's section is doing good enough in the skiing season with all the Kanto tourists going to Hakuba that they said they're not even going to de-electrify it, let alone close it.
>Takayama Main Line
As the name says, it goes through Takayama, so it actually has decent ridership. That said, if JR West lets go of other lines in the area, it might not make sense to have a machine park just for what I assume is one local train(JR West portion is only 36km, and express trains are run by JR Central who owns rest of the line). It would be interesting to see if JR Central would take it if JR West decided to let it go. Even if not, Ainokaze Toyama Railway would probably take it just for passage fees from JR Central and JR Freight.
>Himi Line(top) and Johana Line(bottom), which are on opposite sides of Takaoka station and are not connected
Himi Line is already in talks of being converted to a tram and connected to the nearby Manyosen lines.
Johana Line had the same proposed as well, but I've heard many say it'd make more sense to make it a part of Ainokaze, or even it's own 3rd sector.
>Nanao Line
There is already some separation as JR West owns the entire line, but only runs trains up to Wakura Onsen(which is where the map ends on the flyer), and service further north is provided by a 3rd sector called Noto Railway. However, currently there's one Thunderbird per day go between Osaka and Wakura Onsen on a weekday, with up to 4 on weekends and holidays, but JR West has made a statement that there will be no more Thunderbirds after opening of the Hokuriku Shinkansen extension. Something will change, but there haven't been any statements yet, probably because sides involved haven't agreed yet on what to do.

In part. There is no generic 'track bike' a pursuit bike will be radically different from a pursuit bike. Team bikes are different from individual bikes. A madisson will at least need a bit more of a relaxed geo like a pursuit bike. But the hay days of radical specialisation are over and todays track bikes become more universal, but not universal. Now when it comes to crit bikes there simply is a reasonable cutoff after which the manufacturer can expect not to make any more money because it would be a fun toy but not raceable in a criterium (theres no generic criterium either, courses and rules regarding bikes vary alot) anymore. So they don't make radical sprint bikes with road dropouts and mech hangers for the very few customers who want the impractical novelty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Biggest heaviest fuck off lock
Altor SAF, weighs about 6kg and has a massive ~10cm thick shackle, should last well over an hour of constant attack with an angle grinder, requiring thieves to bring along multiple batteries and cutting discs

>Lighter smaller easily portable lock
Hiplok D1000, havent seen any videos testing angle grinding them but should withstand at least 10-15 minutes no sweat

>not bothered about power tool attacks, just want protection from opportunists with bolt croppers
16mm thick links should be enough to protect you from even the long 42 inch croppers, just make sure you pair them with a good padlock like an Abloy or somethign with a nice thick shackle or one that is enclosed so you can prevent it being exposed at all if you have the right length chain links. Not all chains are equal, case hardening is good and if it's advertised as a security chain it should be better than if its just called chain. Beyond that just be careful you're locking to something that's not going to be weaker than your lock, ideally lock up next to a more expensive bike, or make your own bike look shit, wrap some scuffed up duct tape around the frame or something

I'll give you an example;

(This is Europe btw), you ride into a biggish town, on the outskirts there is a biggish supermarket, the security wont let you bring your bike in so you need to leave it out. What do?
In normal, non-shit tier countries, I've locked mine, and left. No one touched it. I was gone maybe 15-20 minutes.

But what about less nice countries? I am worried for instance leaving my bike out where there are certain culturally-enriched areas. I'm thinking that a cable and u-lock would do the trick for several reasons; cable can go around panniers and a fixed object. U-lock for complete bicycle immobilisation.

As you say, anyone can cut through, but I can sum it up as such:

time left outside multiplied by the skill of a thief can be divided by lock quality and safety of an area.

The "skill" can be regarded as someone with the know how, tools and will to steal your bike. I know it's a bullshit formula, but you get my point. The longer it's out, in a shit area, the more likely a skilled thief will try his chances. Bikes don't spontaneously disappear, good thieves steal from places they regularly see good bikes. Shit thieves are opportunistic. The latter is completely deterred when there is a decent lock present.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1861088
Honestly, the way it's written down makes it look more complicated than it actually is. Alternate law means the plane will obey exactly what the pilot tells it to do, as opposed to normal law where the plane flies the same regardless of speed or weight. Within alternate law the flight computers set some limitations to what the pilot can or cannot command the plane to do, but the pilot should act as if there are no limitations at all. This isn't a case where the limitations nearly caused the plane to crash, like qf72, so i wouldn't put that with any fault of the computers.

The completely disconnected pilot and co-pilot flight controls are FAR more questionable, especially since it averages out two inputs rather than force one side to remain in control, and because the the only warnings for this is a barely visible screen display and an aural warning that is overriden by other more pressing (stall or airspeed) alarms. If i were a lawyer I would focus on that.

The stall warning not sounding below 60 knots has to do with the airspeed indicator not working at that speed, although they could have probably used gear position to to confirm it the plane is on the ground and that the warning can be shut off.

As for the airlines, the real question is how bonin was evaluated as being fit to fly, and if it was legitimate, if the base training must be improved.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1861108
>Alternate law means the plane will obey exactly what the pilot tells it to do, as opposed to normal law where the plane flies the same regardless of speed or weight.
No you're thinking Direct Law. Alternate Law means you still only command load factor demand when yanking the stick back and forth but lateral control can either be exactly like in normal law (alternate law 1) OR with roll in direct where you actually end up controlling the flight surfaces directly like in direct law (alternate law 2) with yaw control in alternate with effectively only dutch roll protection remaining.

Bank angle and pitch attitude protection are always lost and High AoA and Low and high speed protections are either lost or in alternate depending on failure type. That's exactly the point: the pilots didn't really KNOW what kind of failure they were facing but all pitot tubes freezing over meant triple ADR fault so no AoA protection! They didn't even know whether they were in Alternate Law 1 or 2 which is why Bonin was yanking that plane left and right at the beginning, thinking he was still supposed to be giving load factor demand commands.

>The completely disconnected pilot and co-pilot flight controls are FAR more questionable, especially since it averages out two inputs rather than force one side to remain in control, and because the the only warnings for this is a barely visible screen display and an aural warning that is overriden by other more pressing (stall or airspeed) alarms. If i were a lawyer I would focus on that.
I agree, it's a questionable design.

>The stall warning not sounding below 60 knots has to do with the airspeed indicator not working at that speed, although they could have probably used gear position to to confirm it the plane is on the ground and that the warning can be shut off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1874816
stall recovery is the same, with two differences:

1) you'd need to hold the stick forward for a while to give time for the trim actuator to return to the original position after the stick was held fully backwards for so long

2) you might actually need to cut power and add spoilers to slow down the plane once you've regained lift because the plane can gain a LOT of speed as it's falling from thin air. Here's how professional test pilots recover from a snap roll:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L2CsO-Vu7oc

The standby AI on the airbus is just a spinning gyro like the AI in most cessnas, it's not influenced by any computer and it's even reset by hand. 3 adiru's in disagreement means that one or both attitude indicators might be wrong, although in this case they were both working correctly.

Also, I figure the guys in the video were trying to go for an asymmetrical stall, since they were right wing low before it spun around and stalled. Safe to say, if AF447 stalled like that, it would've been over in half the time.
>The standby AI on the airbus is just a spinning gyro like the AI in most cessnas, it's not influenced by any computer and it's even reset by hand.

>trim for attitude on PFD/stnd. and adjust power if required to maintain altitude

posts.name: Anonymous

Yes, at low altitude you need full throttle to climb. And there have been cases of aircraft stalling right after take off that made it.

https://youtu.be/SO3xmzoLzfI

The guys on the video weren't going for any stall at all, they were flight testing the airframe and ended up making an uncoordinated right turn, either because they didn't apply enough right rudder or because the yaw damper wasn't working properly.

That video is useful to explain why they applied speed brakes in af447 - while the forward airspeed was minimal, the vertical airspeed was high enough to make some serious aerodynamic noise.

And yes, the standby speed and altitude sensors also use pitot and static ports, so those were affected momentarily as well.

>>1889982
AFAIK, it's not a matter of the brake system failing, it's that the legacy brake systems brake sequentially along cars out from the locomotive units. This isn't instantaneous, unlike ECP, and according the reports the back 1/3 of the derailed train in this instance was over 40% of the overall weight of the train. So the heaviest cars received braking pressure last, and accordion'd into the lighter cars carrying the gas. If ECP was implemented years ago as originally mandated under the Obama admin, all cars would have received braking pressure at the same and this may have prevented the cars from jacknifing as they did when the bearing failed. Not saying its a panacea, but from what knowledge I have I think ECP could have dramatically reduced the severity of this derailment and railway pushback against ECP is nothing more than CEOs protecting their bottom line to the detriment of every town and city they happen to roll their trains through, just like all the track and car maintenance they've deferred over the past decades to pad their revenue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1890037
>So the heaviest cars received braking pressure last, and accordion'd into the lighter cars carrying the gas.
ECP wouldn't have changed that. The reaction time of the emergency brakes on an ECP train is perhaps one second faster than on a normal brake system (if applied by the crew, if the brake pipe is severed then the reaction time is exactly the same between both systems), and the time required for the brakes to set up is still the same, and the emergency braking force applied is the same as conventional air.

>according the reports the back 1/3 of the derailed train in this instance was over 40% of the overall weight of the train
This is an actual problem, and one that can be fixed long before ECP can be installed on every freight car. Carriers have been running merch trains with shitty train make-up profiles for years now because it avoids switching and therefore saves money.

Consider that carriers all want their crews to use dynamic brakes when possible instead of air, because it uses less fuel and is less maintenance in the long run. As soon as the engineer starts to go into dynamics, the weight of the train is pushed onto the locomotives which provide a force against the motion of the train. If you have a big slug of heavy cars at the back with lighter cars in front of it, that's a potential danger regardless of whether a train has normal air or ECP.

> railway pushback against ECP is nothing more than CEOs protecting their bottom line
Maybe. ECP really shines on heavy trains like unit coal but I think improving train make-up can be accomplished more easily and faster than implementing ECP. We still don't know the cause yet and whether having ECP would have mitigated any of the effects of the wreck.

Seems clear cut to me. Heavy cars in the back received braking force last, since the air pressure is released from the cab. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1890296
>Source?
Working on them, won't be posting paystub though. The air inside the brake pipe moves very fast out to the atmosphere in emergency, even on very long trains. That pressure drop signal is not the same thing as the time it takes for pressurized air to move out of each car's emergency reservoir and into the brake cylinder and begin actuating the brake shoes, which takes a few seconds at best and isn't affected by the ECP system. Essentially, plugging the train with ECP is barely different than without. In-train forces will be slightly higher on the non-ECP train. The ECP train will probably stop slightly faster than the non-ECP one.

The advantage to ECP isn't better train handling in emergency brake applications, it is the ability to smoothy and quickly set air across all cars at once for service reductions, which DOES take longer with normal brakes, as the air inside the brake pipe is still regulated by the automatic brake valve's rate of exhaust and moves much more slowly from front to rear.

>That's a shitty excuse not to implement a better and more reliable braking system,
The reason they're not doing that is cost. But making railroads build their own trains better is something that can start happening nearly instantly and will still be less expensive than national ECP implementation, and will definitely be safer.

>especially when that could prevent a US city from going Lac Megantic.
One-man crew didn't tie his train down properly, ECP wouldn't have changed that.

>All you're telling me is
Nah using dynamic brakes whenever practicable has been a normal practice since the diesel took over. Like locomotives themselves, dynamic brakes have just gotten more and more powerful and effective over time as anti-slip controls became more capable.

>So I see no point in
Cool, buy stock and tell the execs. ECP would be nice but as I said already, safety can be improved nearly instantly and for less money with better train make-up and capping train lengths.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: It comes down to how much range you want and how big of a step between gears you are willing to tolerate. By squeezing more gears in the back you are able to get good range and decent spacing in a 1x config, or even better in 2x with 3x not really being needed anymore. 1x has its benefits, like being about to go to a narrow wide chainring all but eliminating chain drop.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1890684
chain drop isn't a thing on 2x either. A typical road bike doesn't drop chains.
a tight triple can be setup for no chain drop

a touring triple will drop chains if you shift it wrong but that's something you can consciously avoid in a friction setup. It's really user error when it happens.


The real advantages of 1x is that the shift pattern doesn't require mental energy or understanding and setting it up is more straightforward.

They do and it's why quad gates are required for speeds above 90 mph. Brightline operates at 90 around grade crossings, thereby skirting the rule.

In another context, this is why Caltrain has to rebuild all of their grade crossings for California's high-speed rail project as they want to increase speeds from 79 to 124. And I mention Caltrain specifically because the problem you described has been discussed so much, a billion times, a lot, with all miniscule retarded details thought about over on the Caltrain HSR compatibility blog whose owner did a site-by-site analysis of all Caltrain grade crossings. Which, in the context of your question, means quad gates and 90 second gate down time.

And again what you said exists. It's how California determines where grade sep money goes. It's how the 25th Av project in San Mateo and the Rosecrans/Marquardt project in Los Angeles. And it's why the entire Alameda Corridor exists. And it's why there's been over 15 years of discussion online about this topic.

Top speed on this is supposed to be 130 kph. US regulations forbid at-grade crossings above 200 kph.
> it costs less to build a viaduct than to repair trains after collisions
Most of the right-of-way is owned by the Florida East Coast Railway, which does freight operations. The freight company likely wouldn't want to, and creating a plan for elevating the tracks that allows connections to freight at reasonable inclinations would be very difficult. Then Brightline doesn't have the funds to do so, or the time to fight through the inevitable lawsuits without any revenue coming in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1876172
I'm the one saying that induced demand exists, and by implication that even if Brightline West gets the full 12 million trips a year, the actual car traffic on that route won't decrease by anywhere near that amount. The idea that traffic on Brightline West (or any transit option) is 1:1 traffic removed from the roads requires that induced demand not exist.
>What 'holes' are you referring to?
>why would demand for new car trips
Imagine Group A are people who drive from LA to Vegas, and Group B are those who would, but don't due to traffic congestion making it too slow and frustrating for their tastes. Group A move over to Brightline West, and traffic on the I-15 route decreases. Group B see that traffic has decreased, and start driving the route. They do so until the point where congestion and travel times exceed their tolerance, that point then becoming the new equilibrium. Group B are induced car trips. Then there's Group C, those who would never drive to Vegas, but who will fly or ride a train. Group C represents pure induced demand: passenger traffic that would not exist on any mode, but does because of the new option. You can't point to Group C and say "hey, those are cars we got off the road" because they would've never been on the road anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1876203
Except that's ridiculous. Group B undoubtedly exist, but where does this tummy feel come from that they exist in sufficient numbers that they'll replace everybody in Group A? Why are you so sure of this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Furthermore: given that Group B wouldn't drive the route, what would be their reason behind then deciding to drive the route anyway, rather than taking Brightline?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1876208
>they exist in sufficient numbers that they'll replace everybody in Group A
That's not the requirement. The requirement is that they exist at all. Past that point, the size of the group would be proportionate to the degree of capture Brightline can manage (increases the size), and how congestion of the corridor would expand in the no-build alternative (decreases the size). They forecasted that a consistent 50-minute delay for I-15 traffic would lead to an 18% increase in BW ridership, so the elasticity isn't terribly high, even with delay nearing 40% of optimal highway travel time, so Group B would not be large. For the purposes of ridership forecasts, they're just road traffic that doesn't get diverted, but for projects with high modal share/congestion alleviation potential, they would get more attention (if only to show stakeholders why capacity changes aren't 1:1).
Image from
https://railroads.dot.gov/sites/fra.dot.gov/files/fra_net/166/Appendix_F_D_Ridership_Forecast_Review.pdf

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1876209
Brightline West modal share estimates over the years of operation range from ~14 - ~20%. This is from the latest environmental assessment they released for a part of the project, but the shares should roughly hold for all segments.
https://railroads.dot.gov/sites/fra.dot.gov/files/2022-10/Brightline%20West%20Cajon%20Pass%20High-Speed%20Rail%20EA_PDFa.pdf
>their reason behind then deciding to drive the route anyway
All prior posts were working off theory and historical examples (like how ridership on New York's Els changed after the subway opened) rather than the specific facts of the case. Having looked at their ridership projections, there won't be enough congestion/change in congestion to seriously affect driver habits. Indeed, the increase in automotive use on the corridor will be greater than the increase in Brightline use (and by the end, by total Brightline traffic) over the study period.
But there are factors other than travel time that affect mode choices such that someone would still choose to drive even (or especially) if large numbers of others diverted from the roads.

The driver is the primary target but if he fails to pay damages in full it becomes the responsibility of the DMV to complete restitution. >>1889169
Honestly, as much as I hate "le density" meme, it really is that (in North American)
I'll happily cycle anywhere in the urbanized boundary of my city. I know anywhere I go there are desirable destinations around, like places to eat, places to shop, things to see.
I'll cycle through relatively built-up areas, like the waterfront, even if there are gaps. Yeah, there are stretches of cookie-cutter suburban bullshit, or industrial roads ripped up by commercial trucks. But every hour or so I will reach the commercial centre of a town.
I will do longer tours through the rural areas. Past summer I did a four day, 240km trip. But hooooooly fuck was it boring. Fucking ass. Just fucking farm fields for hours, not even "wilderness" except in rare spots. And only 1 or 2 desirable destinations each day (and one of them is the camp ground).

Maybe that's just shit planning, and if I had done 4 days along the waterfront as opposed to 4 days crossing the rural void, that'd be better. But part of traveling is "going places" and if the only two desirable routes you can go purely by bike are "up the waterfront" or "down the waterfront," then you're kinda stuck.

But "le density" can be fixed. Just build more shit, lol. Still tons of fucking space here for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Coffee prior to rides is great (or if you have money to burn and do long ones cafe stops are nice indulgence), studies are there that well establish the efficacy of a reasonable caffeine intake for cyclists. Besides, it’s tradition and good coffee is great, especially in these crisp months that get colder and colder. Personally I would say don’t skip breakfast or do any intermittent fasting type stuff. If you’re trying to shed some weight to get quicker in the long term and conquer hills easier, then cycling fasted isn’t a terrible idea. BUT it won’t feel as good and you’re in much greater danger of bonking early, and your performance will likely suffer if stats and individual rides matter to you. Imo the balanced approach is best, don’t get bloated or stuffed but something no less than an hour prior and maybe a one small snack (sugary is best) during if you go for a couple hours or more hard. Hydration and fuel becomes more critical in the heat and when you’re still adapting to new training demands. At home don’t ruin your efforts by inhaling the fridge but you can enjoy quite a bit of carbs. After hard rides (such as those with lots of steep climbing) upping your protein for recovery is nice, such as having a shake. Mid ride (esp for long ones or if underfed prior) I like clif bars or the equivalent as they provide a nice variety of macros and types of carbs. Pure protein bars won’t give you as much useable energy in the short term and are better for simply staving off starvation and making you feel less hungry, not the best for quick recovery protein either. I do eat probably an excessive amount of junk (White Castle sliders, rice Krispees, ice cream, soda, candy) but if you manage a century or something like that and/or are going hard all week it’s much more excusable.

The question was more about food but water is really important so it should be underscored Drink plenty in total and drink often. It makes a huge impact in how you do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I make my own energy bars, they are basically flapjacks but I don't use refined sugar and put loads of nuts, seeds and dried fruits in them. They taste great and are ideal for taking on rides. They are also much better for you and far cheaper than similar products you can buy in stores.

Ingredients (I make it by feel more than some precise recipe, so play around with quantities)
Rolled oats
Organic trail mix (generic but nice seeds, nuts and fruits mix)
Chopped pistachios
Chopped dried apricots
Chopped Goja berries
Chopped dried apple
Butter
Honey
Soft brown sugar
Maple syrup
70% cocoa chocolate chips
Sea salt
Cinnamon
Ginger

Melt butter, sugar, honey in a pan, add spices and salt, whisk until it emulsifies, fold into the dry mix until a sticky mass, press into a lined baking tin and bake at 135 Celsius until golden brown, about 25 minutes.
Leave to cool in the tin then cut into bars.

Lovely energy rich snack for cycling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1890910
As the anon who recc’d the PHAK, you may wan to look onto the Airplane Flying Handbook. Its really basic airmanship in text form, but maybe its of interest to you.

I also have had LASIK, which I originally got in pursuit of the USAF but I never joined. Between LASIK and PRK, PRK is safer with an apparent month heal time, where LASIK “less safe” and works instantly, a week heal time. Go PRK if you have the time to heal and don’t have to do real vision shit while you wait (driving, reading, etc). I have had zero issues with my LASIK, though in the 8 years since, my vision has degraded about 10 feet per eye, its the same degradation you’d have with or without. LASIK is 99.99% safe in the modern day, as a machine performs the procedure, and the doctor oversees the machine and charges you for the pleasure. All boomer myths about LASIK dangers only applied when it was done by a doctor by hand, the only remaining danger is your eye “flap” never fully heals after LASIK, which is why PRK is slightly safer. Good news, with this flap, you can get LASIK again when your vision degrades enough to justify the cost again. At the conclusion of the procedure, have the eye doc fill out FAA 8500-7, make copies of it, and forward it to FAA OKC, and either keep it on you, or bring it to your AME at your next medical. Its unclear to me if you need a new medical immediately, or can go without until yours expires. The safest route is to get a new medical after LASIK, unless you’ve never had a medical in the first place, then it doesn’t really matter, keep a 8500-7 in case it ever comes up in the futue.

Outside of military aspirations, there is no “real” benefit to LASIK in the cockpit.

I was cycling from work in Northern Norway. It was getting dark sooner by each passing day, which meant it was getting colder. It was a matter of time before it snowed.

As I cycled I noticed the road sparkling in the street light, I didn't pay attention as I was still thinking about work. I was cycling at speed, I took a sharp right, and my whole bike flew under me in the opposite direction.

Hit the ground hard. Bike was OK except for right-side grip tape ripping and my bar-end shifter getting scuffed. Pissed cos my expensive raincoat got ripped.

I had to walk home with my cycling shoes that offer no traction. Black ice everywhere, and it was hell to walk up and down super steep slopes. Took me 45 minutes to get home, when it usually takes 10 by bike...

Got ice tyres eventually, but honestly not worth it how hilly it was.

I got it fixed immediately by my dentist who of course rides. It's the front half of a premolar.

The funny part is it wasn't even from a crash... was a couple of winters ago, on my route I have ridden for years. Had just left an intersection and was getting back in the saddle at around 40km/h when I hit a deep pothole that had cropped up overnight. I didn't notice it due to a thin layer of powder. Just bad timing. I think I may have been swallowing as well, so my jaw was partially shut. The shock slammed it closed. I pulled over and felt around with my tongue but all seemed alright. Wasn't spitting blood so kept going. I was warming up one of my machines at work and took a sip of my drink, then felt it rolling around in my mouth.

At least the bike was alright. Didn't even loosen any spokes. It took a hard hit though, so I gave it an early servicing just to be safe.

this, it's like 1960's Ferrari GTO costing more than 20 brand new top of the range Ferrari 's, there was a golden age where form and function came together to elevate a sport to the status of an art form. Because Mountain biking as a popular sport was only just coming into being at the end of the 80s the industry was caught off balance, it was small time craftsmen and visionaries who were out there building and riding the bikes they built, experimenting and perfecting brand new technology, and so some truly spectacular creations came out of that time, maybe not bikes to beat todays fully evolved machines, but things of beauty from a time where craftsmanship and vision mattered more then marketing, before computer aided design and cheapo chink shit.

It was a golden era where master frame builders and garden shed engineers were able to dominate a new sport from the moment of its conception because the sport was their own invention.

Before the big corporations took over and sucked the fucking soul right out.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1750878

My bike has never been taken care of in its life as well as I take care of it. Ebike conversions give new life to older bikes. I make sure that I can always de-convert it though, no permanent mods to the frame.

I did the pivot bearings, bb, chain, hub bearings, fork service and countless/constant tweaking to perfect this thing. God bless Marzocchi, their forks are the only ones that last forever if you service them. 2004 Rocky Mountain Switch with a Marzocchi Super T Pro. 1x6 with a 30T on the front and a Shimano Hyperglide 14-28 6-speed freewheel on the back. SRAM PC-971 chain and a RD-M786 Shadow+ 10-speed XT derailleur shifted by a vintage Suntour friction thumb shifter. Went with a 6-speed in the back because I needed the extra couple mm to slip into the dropouts without wrestling the thing.

I made two 1/4” steel torque arms to protect/reinforce the factory dropouts and support the 1500W hub motor. 7”/6” travel front/rear, on Schwalbe 2.4” Super Moto-X. KT 18-MOSFET controller, set at 1000W at the moment because 13S4P 12Ah battery can’t push the full 45A (25A BMS).

If you love bikes and electronics then ebike conversions are like combining your two favourite hobbies.

90s mtbs however represent an early stage in their development, and therefore still retains much of the raod DNA that they were evolving out from, and so this is why they are considered peak bike, because they hit that sweetspot between on and off road versatility, durability, reliability, speed, performance and comfort.

Personally I wouldn't consider Paul to be boutique. He and a few others were the answer to fully serviceable derailleurs, in an industry primarily controlled by Shimano along with addressing adjustable shift points such that the derailleur could be used on 6, 7 and 8 speed cassettes and associated shifters without being confided to a Shimano shifter & derailleur with specific indexing. Funnily enough, when Paul and others were released the prices were comparable to XTR...but now...holy shit. GL getting a Paul derailleur under $800 or so.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1754540
Based a f
Early mtb was such a rare happening, a brand new sport, sprouting from a handful of isolated groups doing there own thing to a global phenomenon in less than a decade, think about it, Raleigh, who were at that time one of, if not the, biggest global force in cycling were so caught out by this new craze, that they had to set up a special projects division just to figure out what a mountain bike is and how to get the fuck into the game.

These days fads and crazes are invented top down, thought up by marketing departments and pushed onto the public in the hope that something sticks, the days of kids doing something that they love and that just takes on a life all of its own, completely bypassing the megacorps, forcing them to take notice and play catch up while enthusiasts are already out there pushing the envelope, they're long gone.

Mountain Biking was the last true grass roots consumer revolution, imagine that, a time when people were forced to cobble together the bikes they needed because the industry was too busy inhaling their own farts and churning out cookie cutter BMX, road and commuter bikes to notice what the world was actually crying out for.

Amazing, a golden age indeed, and some of the bikes and parts that emerged from that tumultuous period are simply some of the best ever built.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1750878
Pic is not mine.
But i have just got the same 1960s NSU Sport bicycle. Single speed.

I just overhauled it and its amazing how well everything was made, bottom bracket and rear hub have oil holes so you can re lube them.
Cones in the bearings were easy to adjust because the axles have slots so the nut does not change the cone when tightening.
its pretty lightweight for being a 60s product,
No rust in the tubes because there painted on the inside
It has internal cable routing. the lights and dynamo still work.
the chain was lengthened over 1 link so this thing was definitely rode a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1867932
cont.
The wheels have huge aluminum wingnuts so you can remove them without tools, who needs a quick release lever?

While disassembling nothing was wonky like you hear horror story's of cottered cranks being stuck in eternity, the cotters went out with a few light hammer taps.

>>1868775
Here’s my shelf. All the vertical blue books on the left are from the USMM federal academy curriculum and most of the USCG test question database draws directly from the materials within.
The horizontal book on the top is a personal favorite of mine.

“Fireman NAVEDTRA 10520-G”
Unfortunately it’s been out of print for decades but it’s THE BEST one volume illustrated book for teaching basic oiler knowledge of pipes and valves and pumps. Find a copy if you can.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1867668
It worked for a married couple i knew who were both mariners. Lived in a 26" sailboat moored close to where our company boats were. They got by in a non live-in berth because they kept a low profile and were often gone for long periods. Saved them a ton of money since this was in a major west coast city with crazy rent and housing prices.

>>1868609
Read the sticky, swab.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1868973
I should add that the black bound "Basic Electricity" book on the right of the picture is often touted as the go to for starting your self education on electricity. Its a reprint of another old NAVPERS/NAVEDTRA manual.
However IMO it is written in such an obtuse old style that it gets in its own way when trying to get the information accross. A much better modern text is the "Navy Electricity and
Electronics Training Series"
"NAVEDTRA 14173"
Modules 1-5 will teach you most of whats relevant, in a much more direct style obviously written for entry level enlisted naval students.
They are available as free .PDF online.

On the far right are a collection of random NJATC textbooks on motor controllers, which are extremely common onboard ships and these manuals are written again for entry level young students starting a career in industrial electrical service. Great illustrations and explanations.
"Industrial electricity and Motor Controls" by Miller and Miller is another text that the USCG draws on for questions, but its written for a higher level than the NJATC books and has older illustrations. Still worth getting if you want to study the exact test material.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1879438
The merchant marine is not the military. You only need to be physically capable of performing the job, and have no major medical issues that can’t be controlled by reasonable medication.
Essentially if you can climb up a 20 foot vertical ladder, haul a 1” steel cable up afterwards, crawl through a 24”x24” hatchway and carry 80lbs at waist height for 50 feet you can pass any pre job physical I’ve ever had to perform, and unless you’re diabetic or documented psychotic/suicidal you will pass the USCG merchant marine medical screening.

However I don’t know what specific schools/programs you’re talking about and the best thing would be to call them directly and ask.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1879344
Apply to Ingram and ACBL. Tennessee Rivers and Marquette have bad reputations, for some reason. I couldn't tell you why, I never worked for them. If you get hired by ACBL, volunteer to go to Cairo (kay ROH) IL for training. Or in Convent fleet. Ask, if they don't ask. Convent is really tough, but the 2 weeks will zoom by, and you will appreciate what fleet men do and all your down-time on your lineboat. Anyhow, you will work 2 weeks in the fleet, living in their dorms, or on a laid-up lineboat, and you will learn all your basics. You won't get promoted to full pay, but you will be well prepared. Your mate on whatever lineboat they put you on will respect you a lot just for that, even if he never shows it. Its a great job, but it does suck sometimes. There's an industry-wide, desperate need for watchleads and mates, so there is advancement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1889430
I'm a deck cadet so your experience will differ a lot from mine. I'd say try to apply for a company you wouldn't mind working for after you're qualified, many don't guarantee jobs after graduation but it definitely helps to have trained on the kind of ships you want to work on, but that might be less important for engineers I guess. BP and Shell had very few cadets that I noticed while at college and I heard BP were selling most of their ships, make of that what you will.

About Fleetwood: the accommodation is the worst part of it. They make you stay in halls for 'phase 1' (3 or 4 months if i remember right) in a building which looks like a prison block. The rooms are small, you can hear your neighbours and showers are shared. There is a new halls building next to it which is £40 a week more but has en-suite showers and bigger rooms which you might consider. The canteen food is also mostly shit. The main college building, simulators and short course facilities are mostly very nice. Since you've said you're 'older'; the oldest guy in my cohort was 32 at the start, a couple more were 30 or 31. If you choose the foundation degree route you'll probably have slightly older classmates, I was 24 at the start and the median was probably early 20s. If you go HND or HNC there will still be older guys but also lots of 17-18 year olds. Maybe it won't bother you but having to wear uniform and socialising with a bunch of teenagers did make me feel like a kid, luckily for me we were sent to learn from home during covid and that got me out of halls. You should organise a place to stay in town for phase 3 (returning to college after first sea phase) fairly early on in phase 1

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1889961
Far less demand for ETO on seagoing jobs, no real management position as they’re generally a department of one. Probably higher amount of shoreside jobs that would have you performing almost the exact same duties, however those don’t really pay all that well.

Engineering department officers are in high demand and that’s unlikely to change in the near-midterm future.
Engine officers are highly paid and usually have several people working under them to who they delegate the shitty work. Chief engineer is largely an administrative position.
Shoreside opportunities for engineering officers are abundant and highly paid but don’t usually directly involve the same activities as ship jobs, because they’re port engineers or facilities management.
I’m a chief engineer but I don’t know if I could make the transition to the shoreside jobs.

>>1890661
The thing with ETO is that position on exists on a pretty limited number of vessels, so job availability is poor. There is a lot of work in that area from shoreside support but those jobs don’t benefit from the pay premium that comes with jobs at sea.
Being an engineering officer myself I have a good understanding of electricity and got into (pretty basic) doing electronics as a hobby at home. I used to chat up the shoreside electronics tech at my previous employer and see what he was working on, ended up getting some pretty cool things from him that the company had no use for, old radios and power supplies etc.
That kind of work is probably more stimulating from a creative problem solving standpoint but at the end of the day I assume most of us are in this industry for the awesome money and the lifestyle.

Where I’m at now if we have an electronics problem that goes beyond a power supply issue we just wait till we get back to the dock and then the contractors come in and figure it out.
I’ve chatted with the highly specialized z drive technicians who are a very small group of people, in constant demand across the country, who know way more about these systems than I ever could. It turns out I still make significantly more money than them.

>>1890663
First halfway decent response to mild Bantz.
Here’s my honest answer: as far as I know the only academy with an age limit is the federal academy at Kings point which is a little known military service academy like West Point and Annapolis and has the same entrance requirements like all that congressional recommendations etc.

The other academies are literally just standard 4 year colleges with normal admission requirements so there’s no age limits.

There may be age limits on other programs offered by smaller organizations but even SIU I’m pretty sure doesn’t have one.

Since you appear to be asking about how to become an officer, let me explain this to you: in order to get into and be successful in this industry at any level beyond deckhand, you either need someone or an organization to hold your hand and wipe your ass the whole way (which is what academies do) or you need have a high level of initiative and agency.

This means doing a lot of research on your own, reading the websites of whatever organization is relevant, especially the USCG stuff, and being willing to make a lot of phone calls to get direct answers.

So if you’re in the planning phase trying to decide what school or program is appropriate for you, you need to be calling all of your potentials and speaking directly to them about all your questions.

Good luck old ahh mf with your Rolodex and rotary phone lmao

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Rear rack is the most versatile. You can bungee a small pack to it and the weight carries well in that position.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I want to like frame bags for their look, but I don't really see them as being practical.
The volume and weight you can carry on framebags before you turn your bike into a hobomobile is very low, a 20L backpack will equal the volume you can carry while allowing to carry bigger items.
I can see the advantages of frame bags in that the weight sits lower and most stuff is easily accessible while riding; except you bork you own access to your water bottles.
And once you put a backpack... why even have frame bags? Once you cross the treshold in which volume is better accommodated in a single, bigger bag, the whole point of the frame bag goes away.
Aside from all that rambling, you could use a backpack with those belt pouches, but then again I never owned one of these.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have a frame bag like the one pictured but being on the shorter side it's not really practical for a small frame. I have a small saddle bag for tools, a small topo designs bar bag for snacks or keys/wallet or whatever and then a stem bag if i need to carry another water bottle. On paper it sounds annoying, I get it, but its way more versatile depending on what I'm doing than a frame bag. I rarely ever ride with all three. Also the idea that you can easily grab stuff from a frame bag of style is a myth desu.

I do sometimes wear a backpack when I'm doing a more commuter type ride but its never comfortable or ideal. You'll get back sweat even on a short ride, it just gets in the way, too high or two low. Messenger bags solve this kinda but still not practical for anything other than being a fixie dirtbag (former fixie dirtbag myself)

>>1886619
