>>1874928
My entire drivetrain was replaced new last fall around mid-September. New derailleur, cassette, front chain ring and chain. The chain is a Shimano SLX 12-sp. My average is 600 km/month. We recently had snow which resulted in about a week of wet, salted roads. I kept the chain lubed often except for one day where I forgot to lube resulting in faint chain noise. Shortly after this week of snow I could tell the chain was toast due to how the drivetrain vibrates at high rpm as the rollers of the chain engage the teeth throughout the drivetrain. Checked this morning and was nearly a full 1.00 wear on the gauge.

So on a ‘budget’ shimano chain, installed on a E-cargo bike often times fully loaded in a hilly area, I got roughly 2000km of use. Not too bad, not amazing. For the price, not too bad. Curious to see how the Sram performs when I install one this Spring.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yesterday I was thinking about getting a heated vest for this winter, so I decided to make one. I cut the sleeves off an old faded full zip jersey and attached carbon heat rope. I was aiming for around 15.5 watts power, but it came in a little low at 13.4W. Not instantly hot but heat starts to build after a few minutes. But I did want to stay within the output capability of a single USB-C power bank.

When I was making 9V USB-C heated gloves last winter I also picked up a few 12V USB-C modules one of which I used for this. The higher voltage allows for longer heating loops.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1862308
The most annoying time consuming part is simply attaching the heating loop and wiring to the jersey. Lots of double sided fabric tape, and attaching fabric from worn out cycling shorts to make a channel.

Total heat loop length is 2 meters. I'm glad I drew myself a picture as I was going to wire it as 3 loops. But I realized I could do it as a single piece and attach a positive wire to both ends and negative in the middle for much less work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1862308
>>1862309
That's pretty neat, though frankly I don't understand why you'd want extra heat coming from a vest. Heated gloves make total sense, and heated shoes could be really nice, but after your legs your core is the easiest part of the body to overheat when riding in the cold... at least that was always my experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1862324
For the most part overheating is a bigger issue for me, especially on the fat bike. Many winter rides I'll have my jacket open 1/3 much of the ride down to -15C.

On longer winter rides my core temp often starts to fade towards the end of the ride. I'd probably turn it on after an hour or more. Part of the reason I used a jersey is that I didn't want to add more insulation. Also I dress to be comfortable while moving and get cold if I have to stop for prolonged periods like getting stuck at a long train.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been thinking of getting a dropper post for my fat bike. But for that to work I'd have to stop using my trunk bag. I suppose I could use one my small panniers.

Getting started from a stop when the trails aren't packed it really helps to be sitting. Otherwise the rear wheel spins out as you try to kick off and get up on the saddle. Often that can throw your balance off just enough that you end up veering off the singletrack.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1871008
I'm pretty sure activities warranting a trunk bag are mutually exclusive with activities warranting a dropper post.

I know what you're talking about with the kicking off thing. Sometimes you find pieces of trail where you have to maintain momentum. If you come to a stop it's impossible to get going again. Then you just have to plod on foot until you find firmer ground. I've never thought of a dropper post when that happens. I doubt it will work though. I could be wrong though, so try it and report back. You won't be riding any great distances in conditions like that so you won't need the trunk bag.
If you encounter loose sections out on a longer adventure then just walk it.

Fatbikes really aren't that great on loose terrain like snow or sand as one would like to believe. Pretty good in mud though, in my experience, but I hate having my bike and myself being caked in mud.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Steady around 2C for my ride. The fat bike trails survived the +7 yesterday. More snow tomorrow night which should add to a good packed base, assuming we don't get so much snow we can't find the existing trail. One way to find a buried trail is look for rabbit tracks, they always run on the most packed snow. Often if you come across a rabbit while riding the trail, they just start running down the trail to get away from you.

You see groups of partridges running around together here all winter. Sometimes if you don't notice them, they'll wait until you are a few feet away to fly off. I almost ran over one sitting in the middle of the road at night because it looked like a fast food bag.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1874634
What makes it a fatbike trail? I don't believe you need a fatbike to ride that. Also, how long is it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1874635
Its a fat bike trail because a mtb club got approval from the park to put it there, and arranges the grooming. They can't actually keep anyone off it. The full loop is 13 km.

At the moment a mtb could probably make it around without messing it up too much. But as the snow gets deeper throughout the winter skinny tires cause more an more damage, particularly in corners. Its pretty easy for a mountain bike to dig in at a corner and take out 5" of the trail. After a big snowfall parts of trail get lost and the groomer doesn't line up with the packed trail, and those spots are soft for a week.

Walkers leave divots making for a bumpy ride. If it got lots of foot traffic it would pack down rock hard, but it meanders too much for many people to use it.

Even early in the season when the snow isn't deep, its nice to have a place that's free of salt and sand, and where the studded tires aren't constantly buzzing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: A solder joint in my heated glove that I've fixed twice already went up to over 200F again during yesterday's ride (the connection further up the glove than my fingers usually reach so it wasn't in constant contact). I should have it permanently fixed now by changing how I do the carbon to wire connection. After testing the 3 and 4mm diameter copper tube I ordered, I settled on using 4mm to make crimps. One 300mm copper tube, trimmed into 105 little rings a bit over 2mm wide each. Sliding the tube over a drill bit and using diagonal cutters while rotating the tube half way worked well.

The front of my legs were going numb, so I cancelled that plan and started riding back home. While going back north the temperature went back up to -13C and my legs warmed up. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1879824
It turned out one heater stopped working because a wire got pulled out of the power button. Those heaters were only sold one season due to that design flaw. When I contacted the company after the first time it broke they sent me 5 or 6 extras. The wire is connected to the board with thin 26 or 28 gauge wire with no strain relief mechanism. I duct taped the buttons into clearance bin phone holders back in 2019 and they didn't give me any trouble until today. Except for a green LED burning out last year so instead of lighting up white when on medium, it is pink now.

Being a PILOT is a job that can easily allow you to travel the world (as it is an in-demand skill). Being a BUSH pilot is inconsequential to that.

>Anyways, what’s the job like, being a bush pilot?

I've gotten a little stick time at place that flies into the Alaskan bush. Some might split hairs and say it's not really bush flying because the planes are bigger -but it's close enough for me. The planes are dope, the work environment is really laid back, and rural Alaska is beautiful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1884569
afaik bush jobs in alaska don't typically come with interline benefits, but it sure pays more than here in Canada. An experienced float driver can make enough in a summer to travel all he wants in the off season in Alaska. bush flying is fun, but you have to love flying to stick with it. for you guys in the states it's pretty hard to ignore the rapidly increasing pay and benefits for airline chuds. the weather near the coast and in the mountains can get nasty and has killed friends of mine. other stupid shit entirely outside of your control can kill you too (shit maintenance undetectable through a walkaround, corrosion/airframe stress). Here in Canada most float/bush guys start in the flatlands of Ontario/the prairies before moving west to the coast and mountains for year round work. I heard of a guy who instructed at jack browns in florida and then moved to alaska with some float time. maybe do that. days can be very long in the summer. if you're lucky enough to have a year round gig, the weather can get even nastier than usual (ice, freezing fog, freezing rain, freezing whatever). seaplane pilots are very much in demand everywhere. I chose my niche and have been greatly rewarded for it by staying employed and getting new jobs through Covid when airline chuds were on unemployment. if you like the outdoors and don't mind living in small towns, are independent and don't require excessive hand holding, you can do well.

Here's my concept
>concentric roads with bike lanes and service lanes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not really a flaw, since this is the optimal design, but cities tend to grow on a more human-ish scale, so this sort of city has to be inherently artificial or planned way ahead of time in order to ensure the land for the concentric roads is available. so the main flaw is that for the perfect circular ring road you need to build a new city from the ground up or destroy a few houses in an existing urban area.

It might be better for the city to be hexagonal so that the city blocks are more easy to arrange but that’s just my autism speaking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Oh also this sort of exists in Europe on a smaller scale, perhaps most strikingly is the bastion fort and village of Palma nova. It’s frankly beautiful but it’s a village so the infrastructure is limited to walking or road transport rather than extensive metro or rail links. However it does prove the initial concept. Personally I think it would be more ideal for a city to be made of multiple circles forming a honeycomb arrangement, with each circle representing a distinct borough or community, it would make local administration easier and could also ensure the creation of local markets or identities in an otherwise individualistic urban and metropolitan environment.

That’s less of an issue with cities and more so an issue with the current worldwide financial system. Most money circulation and movement is exchanged between wealthier “safe investment” countries and if not that, in a group of “world cities” that compete to attract capital and investment. ultimately these beautiful cities are ideal for transport, living, and society, but they don’t line up with our current system of how money works. More people are willing to live a miserable life in Paris, New York, London, or Tokyo, where they will have a high salary. In contrast less people are willing to live in these beautiful cities, because that’s just not where the money is.

I live in corte rn, beautiful city, walkable, a bit car dependent but still has a rail network, it stays relevant because it has a university, but if this were not the case it would probably also be experiencing major population decline. ultimately there are two possible “solutions” to this. Somehow get people with money to change the way they make their investments and purchases (cultural change within a capitalist system) or we rely on institutions and individuals from these small neglected populations to change the cities to bring them within the global market. This second possibility does have some flaws though because one rich person can just buy a whole village and make it his personal ancapistan, integrating the city to the world but stripping it of what makes it worth anything. There are probably other things that can be done but I’m too lazy to write an essay

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1874876
>Find a flaw

>concentric roads
Grids are simpler and easier, plus traffic flowing to one central point is just going to create problems. My personal favorite is the grid with street hierarchy, you can make each 1km2 grid unique while still having traffic efficiency and safety.
>NO private vehicles
Yeah, yeah, car hate on a car-hating board. But good luck attracting the rich, people who want their peace/privacy/space, and people who simply like cars/bikes. Better to go the Singapore way and simply reserve 25% of road capacity for cars and auction off licenses. If you don't like on-street parking or big car parks, simply ban that and provide automated underground parking. You will get both income and happy citizens who like cars/bikes.
>with stops at each circle
The distance between the N/S and E/W stations will get wider as you move further from the center, another reason why grids are easier as you can easily provide multiple N/S and E/W lines and a stop every 1km or so.
>inner circle is residential and commercial, outer circle is industry
I thought people here hated that kind of single-zone style? I agree, it creates safety issues, over-crowding in one area and dead space in others, and it creates traffic flow problems. Better to go the current preference of mixed-use zones and also have several key centers of commerce spaced out, eg, Tokyo. (With the exception of heavy pollution businesses and sewage plants, they can stay outside the city centers.) Again, grids do this better than a radial design where all leads to one spot.

>>1874876
>Having an intersection where more than three roads meet.
Ngmi
When you have a central point in a network, traffic is always going to be a nightmare there.
To connect a dense area you want a grid, not a single node where that density is concentrated. Much less one at the center of the city.
Even four way intersections are bad.

Go with a hexagonal grid. Ideally connector ramps if the budget allows so you can completely get rid of stop lights.

With the interior section of the hexagon you could maybe get a little spicy with.
Maybe your circle design could be miniaturized within a hexagon’s district.

>>1875686
And to all austists who like circle shape of the city. It was fallout of barbarian past when city must be walled for defense. Obviously cirlce has minimum wall length (and cost) per walled area. Today obviously that is not an argument.
What’s funny is the grid was also originally also a fortification technique as well.
Each street block would be a “cell” in a fortification and in times of invasion every block of buildings would be fortified into a makeshift fort, each overlooking each other.
This was actually the cited principle behind the grid design of many early colonial settlements.
When towns stopped being vulnerable frontier settlements, the grid design just sort of caught on and became the go-to standard anyway.

> NO private vehicles
You allowed for bikes, bike-based traffic (bakfiets), and other human-powered traffic (scooters). You should allow for pedelecs, and escooters also to help those who cannot use a bike or need help carrying children/lots of stuff.
> Service lanes can be used by ... couriers
Couriers are usually private companies, so you allow small trucks, also, or is it like an USPS monopoly? Unfortunately you have to allow for some trucks even if you ban cars.
> Bus traffic primarily
Especially in the downtown, you need higher capacity modes such as trams. If you want a zero emission utopia, use trolleybuses and trams primarily.
> R+C downtown
You know what fucking high property prices will be downtown? You probably need a dedicated middle circle for residential. You also should mandate high density development, so that your city remains walkable and transit-friendly.
> High speed metro lines on the spine
... aaand that's where your commercial, shopping districts, hospitals, etc. are
> by rail
Where are your train stations? They should use the same tunnels as your metros, ideally the same tracks with 4 lane tunnels. Two outer for the rails, two inner for the metro. The trains stop at downtown, and in major suburban centers like Paris, Vienna, German cities with S-Bahn. Also they stop at industrial centers overground carrying mostly freight, bit the same lines can carry passengers. Ideally, since your trains stop at high density commercial centers anyway, you could build warehouses and a freight train stop underground next to the train stop . That's how you supply the city with 0 carbon.

Also:

>>1887902
ADFC organises swap and trade meets. Check their website.

Also do a web search 'Fahrrad Bedürftige' and maybe include the closest town. Youll find one of those browney organisations. Everyone who is poor or a literal nigger qualifies. Take a student ID card or whatever people on benefits have with you or just be black.

Which is it, you CANT find a bike for 50€ or 100€ or those offered at that price point don't seem enough of a bargain to you ?

I cant make economic decisions for you. Groupsets of yesterday mean nothing. You want a bike that works really but much more one you personally dig. You can always get a derailleur or a set of brakes for almost free if you arent happy with all the components.

If I was you I'd make sure I know what I can and what I can't fix and be realistic about it. If you dont think you can fix bent and dented tubing, fucked BB threads, cracked joints or such thing then avoid those things naturally.

Search local so you can take a train or bus there and ride the bike back home, test it and then step back for a minutey go for a walk, make up your mind and tell the guy. Don't feel pressured to buy, dont fall for sunk cost fallacy, dont hesitate to ask about taking things apart and having a look.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1812571
>Obahn
I don't think the Obahn can be converted to heavy rail, the gradients up that way aren't appropriate for it. Now that we're slowly bringing the tram back though I reckon the Obahn will be rebuilt as a tram line once it reaches the end of its functional life. Trams can definitely work up there.

It wasn't originally built as light rail because back then our tram line was pretty much just a tourist attraction that terminated in the middle of Victoria Square, the idea of rebuilding all the tram lines was seen as a bit kooky in the 70's and 80's.

>Underground loop
I think a loop could be built and that Adelaide Station could be changed from a terminus to being part of the loop. It'd cost an absolutely fortune but I'd dig out the entire train hall (if you can really call it a hall, lol), dig it down a level or two. There's enough of a leadup to the station from the triangle by the old gaol that everything would nicely and neatly go down quite deep by time you reach the station. The train hall would now be an actual hall which would have the bonus of making it not feel so claustrophobic in there, and you could then dig under the station and build your loop round the CBD.

I've massively oversimplified my idea, it'd require a lot of jiggering around of existing rail lines to get them all hooked up properly to the loop, but it could be done. It's just a question of political will and, more importantly, money. Sadly due to the latter it'd probably never happen, not in our lifetime anyway.

I doubt there's enough demand for services to Canberra to justify the expense of HSR, and even if you bypass Canberra or pass through it the distance between Melb and Syd is too great for it to work economically.

Face it fampai, it's something of a pipedream. A more realistic proposition for rail travel between Melb and Syd would be to improve the track alignment between the two cities to shave an hour or two off the current 11 hour travel time, and then also engage in heavy promotion and public acceptance of the conveniences of sleeper services. People might be more convinced to travel by train if they're made aware of the merits of sleepers.

This is just me speaking anecdotally but I've spoken with various normie friends and acquaintances over the years here in Adelaide who say they'd be more likely to try using the Overland if it was operated as a sleeper service. The idea of spending the travel time asleep instead of wasting a whole day watching flat nothing pass by the window is a lot more appealling, especially if the ticket prices are sensible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The first thing you should do is get some cone spanners and attempt to overhaul the hubs. You'll need 13 for the front and 15 for the rear, plus a 15 & 17mm regular spanner. A tiny lil vice helps to set preload. You also want some grease, preferably a small tube with a nozzle, tweezers, new ball bearings if the ones you have aren't shiny still, or else just clean them, and kerosene. If those cones/cups have pitted bearings then they won't be better than ones off a new shitter. You can possibly replace both but might struggle to source ones, especially ones which will still seal.
Also scrutinize the brake track for wear, and see how (roughly, like none are super loose) evenly tensioned the spokes are and how true you can get it and if there are bad gouges in the rims which will affect braking.

Actually good condition wheels are the rarest thing about rehabilitating old bikes, and servicing them is the most work.

What you're planning to do is retarded but if you actually do it properly you'll learn a lot. And if those wheels have double wall rims and STX hubs and are miraculously in good nic then they will be quite a lot better than a decathalon shitters.

this is semantic nonsense. Many hybrids are fairly aggressive and many road bikes are not.

Also 'comfort' is a misnomer. You will be uncomfortable climbing out of the saddle on a bicycle without much reach. An aero position is not necessarily uncomfortable for a trained person. Managing fatigue after all is one of the most important parts of performance, and any acute discomfort is going to severely limit how far you can ride and how much you can train.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1884164
I think a balls on the top tube fit is usually good unless it makes the bike too long.
Balls on the top tube means you're riding the largest frame size you can, and the front end is as high as it can be, meaning either it facilitates high bars, or, a small/stiff stack.

If you look at pic rel, this setup is obviously not balls on top tube, they've sized down, but the front end could be WAY higher than it is now, with a riser stem and riser bars, and it could be closer too, with swept bars.
I wouldn't normally recommend a flat bar bike, or a singlespeed, but they are absolutely the easiest to modify the fit on.

You will find when you actually ride a bike rather than just test ride or cruise it, that 'as upright as possible' is not comfortable. An arched back and being able to stretch out some will work better for riding. So don't overcompensate. Remember bike sizes change in 2cm increments, it's easy to achieve more than that with your cockpit.

Basically you want a bike that is taller than it is long, and as tall as you can stand over, and then you will be able to make it work for you by adjusting the cockpit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1884178
So I definitely recommend a drop bar endurance road bike, with claris or sora groupset.

You can get the bars up with a different stem, and possibly reduce the reach with more compact bars. You'll have to budget to experiment with stems, and re-cabling the bike. It's a worthy expense because fit is the most important thing on a bike.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1884164
>balls rest on TT
The ballsack test is a rough rule of thumb. It depends on things like sloping top tube, tyre size and BB height. As long as the top tube isn't j-j-jamed up in your junk when you're standing over it it's probably fine. In fact, if your balls are hanging completely free above the top tube I'd take that as an indication the frame _might_ be too small.

> feel neck strain cause I got to look up to see the road
Very common complaint with people not accustomed to riding a road bike. It takes a fair bit of training to get used to. Question is if that's something you're willing to go through.
And don't slam your stem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Basically you should be able to fit an entry level / endurance road bike to have the drop bars at your saddle level. That is a reasonable relaxed position, and to ride into wind etc you favour the drops more than most other roadies would. That is a sensible fit.

If you desire them to be -above- the saddle, you should train core strength, flexibility, do planks, get gud, etc. Or look into a meme type of bike. Above the saddle the problem is you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1889398
I somewhat like it on a theoretical level. I do think rail companies in North America are under-utilizing and under-investing in their infrastructure.
Go on aerial imagery and look at rail right-of-ways in cities. There are frequently areas with space for more rail that are just barren. Or if there are 2 or 3 rails, only one is serviced enough to be used at-speed and the others are just siding—or even just "storage" for rails they can cannibalize.
At least locally, it's suburban commuter rail run by government agencies that will actually buy the corridors (or lease as much of it as the railroad will allow) and invest in putting down rails. The demand is there in cities, but the private-sector will to invest in infrastructure is not, without government intervention.
And I'd rather government intervene in a sensible way and own the infrastructure, rather than something stupid like shovel money to the private sector that builds half the network they promised and pockets the rest. You want competition for the tender to build something, rather than sole-sourcing the tender to someone because they "own" the land. Eminent domain that shit at the present value of that rotting line, then make something good out of it.

That being said, I think it's very poor value-for-money right now for the state to step in and nationalize entire railroad companies. Better to focus on specific projects, buy up the right-of-ways in cities, and then set up smaller state enterprises to run just those sections, where rail users might be in conflict with one another (freight, commuter rail, interurban passenger service) and have perverse incentives.

>>1888857
>it's clear they didn't want to make a game
I don't think that's the case at all. For this kind of introspective meditative spiritual crap there's a huge benefit to having some interactivity. The kind of blurred lines between character and player that you get from having to control them lets you have experiences feel directly personal. If you wanted to do that with film you have to rely on empathy for a character that the viewer is definitely not at all a part of and so you have to do something completely different.

There's a lot of these artsy games because there's a pretty reasonable audience for them and that audience of artsy people is sort of predisposed to people wanting to make their own games (and actually giving it a shot). Basically the same mechanism as how schlocky horror films proliferate. It's a very separate audience to the /v//reddit/youtube AAA shill bubble.

You could either go for something like Kenshi but with bikes, big free roaming world where you need to plan out everything carefully. Your setup would determine which routes you could do, where you could camp, if you could carry enough food / water until the next place to resupply etc. Or the alternative would be a bike metroidvania, like metroid prime with a bike. You crash land on an alien planet and have to collect parts to upgrade your bike so you can get to a place where you can escape. Things like spider ball type wheels, or mini boosters so you can jump gaps etc.

What makes things float?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1880179
You float if you have lower density than the fluid around you, and sink if you have higher density. To float in water you must be lighter than water and to float in air you must be lighter than air. Usually you would achieve this by having a light substance contained in a shell that prevents the heavier fluid from getting in. Ships float on water because they are full of air and airships float in air because they are full of helium. This is the principle of buoyancy.
A vacuum balloon works on the same principle, but instead of filling it with something lighter than air you simply suck all the air out of it until it has a lower density than the air around it. The drawback is that you end up with a pressure difference of almost 1 atmosphere, which will cause the balloon to collapse unless the shell is very strong and rigid. The shell must also be extremely light, however, otherwise buoyancy will not be achieved.
So you basically need a very thin shell of low-density material that is capable of withstanding 1 atmosphere of pressure without breaking or deforming. You might be able to do this with some kind of exotic composite material, but it likely be very expensive and difficult to mass produce at first.

>Most airship disasters have been caused by a loss of control.
Shenandoah crashed because of construction defects (insufficient number of dump valves) stemming from cost-cutting. Macon crashed because of a structural design flaw (that was supposed to be corrected, but funding was cut, IIRC). Akron was more debatable, whether it was just the storm, or the storm plus the same kind of structural design flaw as her sister. Los Angeles had no notable issues and ended up scrapped. Ironically, she was the only one built by the O.G. creator, Luftschiffbau Zeppelin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
MTB has wider tires that don't have to be filled up with as much air pressure. They also normally have shocks/suspension that absorb a lot of bumps from rough terrain. This makes a relatively comfy ride even on a rigid bike.

Both of those things are less efficient than the thinner, higher pressure tires and rigid frames on a road bike. Road bikes are also designed to put you into a position that's more aerodynamic than the MTB and happens to be less comfortable. There are some frames and styles within road bikes that might be more comfortable than others, I'd imagine a touring or cyclocross/gravel bike to be more comfortable than a track bike for instance, but I can't say that it'll be as comfortable as your MTB.

I think it's just a compromise thing, and you just need to figure out what level of comfort to speed is good for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1887346
They do the same shit here whichbis why I only use alloy beaters or carbon stuff for winter.

You can not convert rust back to steel that is integral to the part. But you can and should remove oxidation and prevent further oxidation.

Disassemble the bike, take off every bit and wash it all with fresh water. Make sure to pour everything out of the frame and let it dry upsidedown.

Then remove the rust. Do not use acids including tannine or caustic cleaners (EDTA is okay). You want to make use of a celating agents that is your safest bet. You can always consider to not use chemical agents but mechanical removal of rust, get brushes, sanding cloth, steel wool or abrasive pads and go to town. You will loose any finish (paint) that might still ecist by doing so but where there is rust there was no paint to begin with. Make sure to get it all off. Rinse again, dry it fast.

Then prevent rusting it again: Paint the frame, or wax it.

>>1887389
That philosophy is new and only applies to modern composite bikes.
When shopping for a steel (or by extension aluminum but that might be up for debate) track, especially sprint bike, me and most people I know downsize for very simple reasons:
A smaller frame increases stiffness. This guy is shopping for a track bike and probably wants to mash it, and not spend hours in the saddle keeping tensio on the chain.
A smaller frame, assuming were talking about a constant S/R ratio for the purpose of discussion, comes with a comfort penalty. The argument is the same: Comfort is a non issue, a bike like this is meant to go fast, for as long as your anearobic capacity allows.
A smaller frame means you'll have your seatpost sticking out, which reduces rigidity for a SEATED rider thats got a bit of tension in the chain. See above as to how much that applies. You want that drop tho.

So yeah if you want a comfy ride get a road bike. If you want a ride that is fast get a tri bike, if it needs to be compliant a TT bike. If you want it to feel fast get a crit bike. If comfort isnt a necessity and you want to sprint on a metal bike: Get a small track frame.

>A smaller frame increases stiffness
>A smaller frame means you'll have your seatpost sticking out, which reduces rigidity

The same applies to having a longer stem or any stack. A smaller frame is only stiffer if you are also a smaller rider. Otherwise you're just talking about preferring a different fit.

It's also common on high-end steel bikes for extra beefy tubesets, or single tubes mixed in, to be used on the larger size frames. They are (should be) specifically designed for heavier, stronger, riders, not just the same thing scaled up. Columbus SP etc, with thicker walls. My experience riding (fancy) classic steel road bikes is that the big ones tend to be a lot stiffer -even- sprinting out of the saddle on the same bar, so, aggressive setup, but especially if you fit them similarly.

I also don't buy your argument about not desiring comfort on a fixie. Unless the bike is actually for training and racing on a velodrome, you're buying a steel fixie, you're gonna spend a fair bit of time cruising it around. So many fixiefags I see are clearly enduring an uncomfortable fit for no reason and are far too often perched on the unwrapped tops out of desperation. Their bike may look cool posed against a wall with graffiti on it but it doesn't look cool when they're riding it.

StVZO merely means it complies with german regulations for road worthiness. Particularly asymmetric lighting profile, where the light 'cone' tapers down to the left as to allow for good illumination of your lane while avoiding blinding oncoming traffic even at breakovers. Not blinding oncoming traffic is a matter of correct setup, with any lighting cone, be it symmetric or not.
I just want decent light for the road. I do set my light up correctly of course, people who fail to adjust and use their lights incorrectly, wether cagies or bikers, annoy me alot after all. Also I dont see the point in trying to illuminate the horizon.
Now the light has several settings. If you turn it up all the way the road infront of you will be decently illuminated. But the battery will be flat, from a full charge in no time. Yet the light will not reach to the sides, like at all, which means if you want to take a turn without going in blind youll have to sway on the approach to get a chance to look.
If you turn it down the battery last longer but still not all night, the road, as in your lane, ahead is still illuminated plenty and you can see no more or less to the sides than on the highest setting.
Quality seems decent. They ship a gopro style mount, the screw included was too short to engage the thread. Thats not a good sign. I bought one that works.
Btw I bought this light specifically for the rare ability to be mounted to your stem with factory supplied parts because of the aero bar compatibility.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1888051
You'll achieve that with tires.
Your rims will likely be wide enough to fit tires that are as wide as the frame clearance will allow.
The only benefit 'mtb' wheels might give you is to be stronger, which is not desirable unless the hybrid wheels get fucked up, which probably won't happen, so why not just ride them and replace them -if- that not happens, not in case it might. And on your budget you probably wouldn't even get nice replacement wheels anyway nor would they make sense on your shit hybrid.

As for the tire choice, 700c and 29" is the exact same size. 2" is about 50mm. So whether you run ~45mm 'gravel' tires or ~2" 'mtb' tires doesn't really matter. You want as wide as the bike will fit for your purpose. The gravel tires will actually probably be better. Just beware, many gravel tires, especially on narrower rims, will run one or two sizes under, especially schwalbe.

Your whole upgrade should just be getting expensive tires.

cassettes wear unevenly. if you ride the same chain and cassette long enough, the chain is eventually going to start skipping on the gears you don't use as often.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1888083
>the cassete's gonna need replacement after that big ammount anyway
Conventional wisdom is to change the chain for a fresh one regularly specifically to extend the cassette life. Meaning that if you don't replace the chain the cassette's gonna need replacing well before that amount of of time. And if you don't replace the cassette when it's shot, the tail end of that stint the ride is gonna suck.

But you ride a hell of a lot more than I do, so I imagine I'm not saying anything you didn't already know. You're in a prime position to experiment with various permutations and figuring out an optimum for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1888083
Depends on what kind of parts you're using and how much the parts+labor bill would be when it's time to replace. Cassettes cost more than chains and chainrings cost more than cassettes. Low-end cranksets are cheaper but unlikely to have replaceable chainrings so you have to replace the whole thing. If you don't mind replacing the entire drivetrain every couple years then sure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1888379
Also are there any books that dives deeper into the technical design behind some of the modern bikes? I'm seeing stats like seat tube angle and other metrics being part of the marketing process. I can infer that different angles = different shift of weight and center of mass, but i would like something a bit more...comprehensive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1888379
braking performance matters and all the pro teams are using disc brake bikes. electronic shifting is also the norm on high end bikes. 19+ mm internal width rims and 28+ mm tires have become the norm on road bikes, 23mm tires are not a thing. the UCI has relaxes the rules so that the newest aero bikes can be significantly more aero and they've become lighter than they were before, the climbing and allrounder bikes have also gotten some aero features in the frame tubing shapes and internal cable routing etc. improvements in compliance have been made with D-shaped seatposts etc. carbon is still the preferred material for performance if money is not an object, an aluminium frame with a carbon fork is what you get at the entry level although some of the chinese carbon frames might be viable if you know how to research parts and build up your own bikes. there are chinese groupsets which are not as good as the high end groupset from the big 3 brands but they're a decent poorfag cope. if you want to get very serious into cycling you might want to look into things like power meters and heart rate monitors, there's also a garmin device with radar that detects cars behind you that a lot of riders who've tried it swear by.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: there's also carbon spokes although they're mostly seen on chinese wheelsets for now

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
also tubeless tires are a thing. tubeless sealant can seal minor punctures and you can have run-flat tire liners in them. they supposedly have better performance although they're probably similar in weight and rolling resistance to a comparable tube-type tire with a lightweight inner tube. all but the very cheapest bikes have tubeless compatible rims. a lot of casuals are still using tubes though, there's also TPU inner tubes. a very recent development is hookless rims but they're currently only rated for 73 psi (you're supposed to use wider tires and lower pressures though) and not many people are using them yet, might be a marketing flop or it might be the way of the future who knows.

>>1888444
>is it safe to use gasoline to remove rust on my bike?
It's not safe to touch with your hands, so wear nitrile (not latex) gloves. It will fuck up your skin and is bad for your health generally

Sheldon and others (me) also advise not to use gasoline for cleaning as it has a very low flash point (-45°F). Vapors from it will creep long distances and can easily ignite. This makes the rags you use very dangerous too.
On the other hand Kerosene, has a flash point of 100°F, so it's relatively safe. That's what I use. Gasoline also smells a lot worse imo.

>is it effective to use gasoline to remove rust
Would work ok, but imo wd40 (i use crc but it's the same) is better for that. The actual correct thing to use is called 'evapo-rust' which is really quite amazing. Also i suggest aluminium foil for rust removal on chrome, it won't scuff it. You need to kind of bunch it up and change it often, but it works well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1888599
Neither gas nor WD-40 (mineral spirits) or any other hydrocarbon product will remove rust. Those products will, if anything, assist in flushing what you remove by mechanical means. Nothing more. So get something to scrub and start scrubbing, dry or with any liquid. Go gentle first with nylon, get whats left with a brass brush, steel wool and lastly abrasives (which will cut into good material).
Remove all oxidation. Paint right afterwards.
If you want to convert iron oxide be aware that you can not convert it back to elemental iron that is integral to your part. But you can convert it to compounds that are mostly inert or easier to remove.
I said it before: If you want to be absolutely sure you're not degrading remaining good material, do not use anything acidic or caustic (including soda, coke, tannic, phosphoric, citric...). Instead use a complexant like EDTA, get EDTA-2Na or -4Na which are soluble in water. Dissolve and bring to neutral with citric acid. Treat rust by submerging for up to a day. Your ferric edta will dissolve in the solution and leave bare metal behind.

I'm not being pedantic I'm clearing up false information that has been provided. I merely noted that it is the mechanical action that removes rust when someone 'removes rust with gas' and they will get the same effect doing it dry. Especially if were talking surface rust here, or abrasive pads. Surface rust just wont be enough to ever load up your sandpaper, abrasive pads are specifically engineered to resist loading up. So only when removing heavy rust using sandpaper you want to flush with any liquid.

The oil will not 'treat' rust. Also WD-40 will not seal bare metal as it's literally petroleum with perfume and will evaporate completely. This is exactly why many competitors to WD-40 have formulated their products with either added dry lubricant or added longer chain hydrocarbons. Because numbnuts don't understand shit and make mechanisms that need lube worse.

So either paint or smear with oil after removing rust. Bare steel will rust in no time. It's not asking too much to take a brush and a drop of primer. You can always give it a complete once over if the spot repairs pile up and give the frame a shitty look.

To me the whole concept always seemed dumb desu. But I see them all over the place:
Isn't the basic assumption that your hub is lacking stiffness to the point where it will twist ? Because if its not that, it wouldn't matter if they crossed the drive or the non drive side. And while there is no such thing as an infinitely stiff body for this purpose theres no room for the argument to be made that it mattered.
Secondly they are replacing 3 cross on two sides with 2 cross on one side. So they are replacing say 36 spokes at an acute angle for 18 spokes at a shallow and another 18 at no angle. To me this seems like it must be a big step down in stiffness. Can't it at least be laced 3 cross and radial ?
So besides agreeing on it being seemingly stupid: Is it just a weight saving meme or is there other supposed benefits ?

posts.com: They're not the same though: fare evasion hinders the ability of transit to remain operational. Parking meters exist to keep parking spaces available by limiting occupancy times and parking tickets for small infractions are issued to reinforce that function. If someone is similarly disruptive when parking, by parking across multiple spaces or leaving their car for an extreme period of time, then their car will be towed and that's the penalty you should be comparing to the fines for fare evasion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1889115
Depends on if your transit agency/street parking authority is privatized or not.
If privatized, then yeah, the agency is within their rights to pursue it as "theft under $5,000" (at least what we call it here).
But if the agency is public, then both are stealing a few dollars from the public purse. Money is fungible, and who gives a shit whether you stole that money out of the bag marked "parking" or the bag marked "transit." A dollar is just a number in a spreadsheet.

And the "public space" argument you make here is no less damning.
Yes, a space in a bus/tram/subway is slightly more "expensive" to offer than a space on the curb of the road in dollar figures (though, I would hope everyone pro-transit argues transit is more efficient if we stopped externalizing costs onto other parties).
But the space by the curb has a large, non-monetary opportunity cost. Every space we devote to people storing their private property is space that could have been used for more throughput of vehicles (cagers love this!), or for throughput of bicycles, or for transit right-of-ways or even just an extra transit stop, or just to store snow because my examples are all Canada and sometimes we need a place to keep snow for a few weeks until it melts.
If we value efficient use of our curb space at 3 / 20 the value of our public transit spaces, then why the fuck do we have so bloody much of it?

Anyways, all distractions from what I hoped was the core point of the thread. I want to hear your anec-data! In the spirit of not grifting off other's hard work, here's some more figures:
>New York City, $35/$65 unpaid meter, $100 fare evasion (wow, if we use the 65% that's looking pretty good!)
>Paris, France, £35/£50, £50-£180 fare evasion (holy shit, actual parity here if paid on-the-spot)

So there's two cities I'll need to look into a bit later and see if there was interesting public debate around those figures. May learn something about advocacy techniques.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Post experiences about rail replacement services in your country or city.

Currently in Hamburg, the lines U2 and U4, that share the eastern section, are currently closed for preparation works to extend the U4, causing a replacement service. I am positively surprised at how well the replacement buses run. Previously you would have one bus replacing one metro train which was of course not feasible at all, but now there are six to seven buses running every ten minutes and some buses even have space enough so only few people would have to stand.
How does your country handle rail replacements? I would like to know especially from Londoners, since they seem to have extensive weekend closures every week.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

Absolutely abysmal in Toronto, Canada. They started doing upgrades to the signaling on the main subway line about five years ago, necessitating replacement bus service.

>>1866425
That hub slips into neutral so often it's absurd.

Chain tensioning is too much for most homeowner riders to comprehend. A derailleur does that automatically.
The 2x/3x derailleur requires more learning curve but offers higher range, and the newer 1x drivetrains do better than most other hubs, at a fraction of the cost.
There're trade-offs for sure, but if Shimano Nexus was around in the '60s and onward it'd have had better implementation and more mass-adoption, but even then there're technical hurdles.
I used to love my IGH until I gave up, bought cheap shit derailleurs, and learned to stop worrying about whether I'd slip into a "neutral" at random.
Stop roleplaying a tweed old britbong.

For navigation, charts are mandatory if you plan to survive any decent trip without the help of emergency services.
Use OpenCPN or OpenSeaMap on a simple laptop or tablet, should be good enough.

For weather, www.passageweather.com is a nice resource.

But yeah, this is a pretty bad idea in general, especially if you have no experience. People who knew what they were doing crossed oceans in such boats, people who didn't ran aground on the first river bank.
Apart from that, boat maintenance is not easy and not cheap.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A haul out to baseline it would be wise, look for fucked up through hulls, blisters/damage, replace the zincs, clean and recoat the bottom.
Go through the mast, static and running rigging looking for wear and cracks. Make sure all seams and joints are shipshape, check the chainplates and other potential leak points.
Get an AIS transponder so you won't get run down. Get and register an EPIRB or PLB for emergencies.
Check all hoses/pipes for wear/age/abrasion/leaks.

I'd say 100+ hours under sail plus basic certifications in various weather situation would be my threshold for going distances.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1883102
I did a little bit of yacht racing a few years back. There is always something that goes wrong when sailing, and it’s always a very expensive and sometimes hazardous. She should know first aid and eater rescue, all her knots and rigging (only sail with a mainsail), swimming, navigation, and meteorology. She’ll be able to find people to teach her for no charge if she’s part of a club so long as you don’t make it seem like that. There’s electrical and mechanical maintenance that needs to be done and regularly checked, but she should really get to know a sailmaker as ripped or lost sails are very much a common thing. She’ll also need to regularly scrub the hull and keel, which is usually done SCUBA diving, so she should get some familiarity with that if she’s not hiring someone.

Your friend did something very stupid. It may be cheaper than rent, but the amount of time and money you’re putting into maintenance, repairs, and insurance will negate that.

My advice; take her out and she won’t be able to refuse (because of the implication.)

To add on to this, I use the Navionics app on my phone for charts for day sailing. Windfinder is a good app for weather, along with Ventusky and Windy. It's nice to have multiple sources because different forecasts will have different underlying weather models.

Only other things I think I can add that hasn't already been said is to be sure she has a good anchor and rode and knows how to anchor safely and securely. Also make sure she's paying for all and any additional parts she'll need, so she'll know just how expensive it is to keep a boat in sailable condition. The ocean is not a friendly environment, even if she's only day sailing and sitting at anchor. Definitely needs classes before attempting anything more than daysailing.

Nah I live in NZ and the cops more or less ignore cyclists and won't help you with anything.

The few times i've politely asked for help from a cop they act like i'm harassing them, but they'll wave you through breathalyzer stops, they don't care about riding the wrong way down streets, on footpaths (illegal), locking to anything, lane splitting, safely running red lights, speeding down hills, not having brakes or reflectors, etc, unless you did something blatantly reckless right in front of them.
They do sometimes harass you over helmet laws which is mildly annoying but it's as simple as 'oh ok sorry', it's not a fine unless you whinge back to them.

DOC rangers look after cyclists. They're helpful authority figures, who will give you water and advice and a lift if needed and stuff and so when they try to impose rules like asking you not to ride a road at night or bring your pet stoat, it's fair.

If you live in a hilly area you are pretty much fucked since all road will have some general ups and downs.
Usually the larger and important the road is, the smallest is the climbing gradient. Smallest roads sometimes have the bad (or good) habit to have steep walls with 10 - 12 % inclines.

This is based on my experience in italy. Your country might be different.

Also after the climb there is the descent. Dont you like to go fast?

>>1883567
A driver's license test and CDL test are for different things. The CDL is to make sure you're familiar with specific safety systems (like brakes), vehicle inspections, and adhering to commercial motor vehicle laws. Regular DL test is do you know what signs are, what speed limits are, basic rules of the road, and so on. They're tests for different things but if you want a CDL you should already have driving experience and thus a driver's license.
